From carla at bratgrrl.com  Fri Jul 14 10:14:51 2006
From: carla at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2006 10:14:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] apache2
In-Reply-To: <727fc2ee0607132359w7c196176q2cc76f12ce1f3cf1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <727fc2ee0607132359w7c196176q2cc76f12ce1f3cf1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200607141014.51553.carla@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 14 July 2006 00:00, User Iam wrote:
> 
> Ok
> 
> Having a problem ?with apache2
> 
> 
> Carla isn't helping
> 
> She wants me to put stuff in /etc/apache2/httpd.conf ?<page 429>
> Should I really put stuff there?
> 
> Apache2 really wants stuff in /etc/apache2/sites-avail/default.
> 
> As far as I can tell..
> 
> Anyone know a good how to???
> 

 Like everyone else said, different distributions muck with Apache in all 
kinds of ways. Debian/Ubuntu uses apache2.conf, not httpd.conf, so you should 
stick with that.

/etc/apache2/sites-avail/default is handy for managing virtual hosts. But if 
you don't have any virtual hosts you don't need it. Or you can put them 
somewhere else entirely. Look in apache2.conf to see where all the 
configuration files are that Apache is using. You can tweak these to your 
heart's content. 

Look in /usr/share/doc for the installed Apache help files, these should help. 
Apache is so flexible, and the different distros so pointlessly different, 
your best bet is to learn about httpd.conf/apache2.conf options as well as 
you can.

Use apt-get, using dpkg is like using rpm instead of Yum. Try this:

apt-get remove --purge apache*

That should nuke all your Apache installation. It might leave a few configs, 
even with the --purge option. So check /etc and manually nuke any leftovers.

a DVD drive.

I had previously installed SuSE 10.1 on this drive in another laptop. I 
just went ahead and ran the installation again, and was given the option 
of a "New Installation" or an "Update". I choose a New Installation, 
assuming that this would be needed to find the appropriate drivers for 
the 600E.

I chose "local" for the hardware clock, (as I remember something about 
this being correct if you are also going to use the machine with that 
"other" OS, which I will), and a KDE desktop.

I did this twice. The first time I got one failure which was related to 
not finding a British spell checker for Firefox. I chose to ignore that 
and allowed the installation to finish. It reported that there was a 
failure, and then would not boot, saying "Missing operating system" just 
after reporting that there are 163264 KB OK. POST gives its usual one beep.

The second time I tried the load, the installer only got as far as 
looking for and not finding a "catalog".

Both of those actions sound to me like the DVD has problems. I still 
have the ISO on my other laptop. At the moment I can't seem to locate a 
program that will burn the data! I know I burned it there before, since 
that's the only DVD burner I have. I'm pretty sure I ran NTI 
CD&DVD-Maker, which is the XP program that came with the Acer Aspire 
laptop. But, when I try to create a new data dvd I get an error message 
that says, "The ISO filesystem has a 2GB limit on individual file size. 
File "SuSE-Linux-19.1-GM-DVD-i3a6.iso" has exceeded this limit and 
therefore must be skipped. If you want to include large files, please 
choose the UDF filesystem ... (there is one more line in the error 
message, but the line of buttons obscures all but the top pixels of the 
characters!).

I poked around in the NTI program and found a way to go with UDF, and 
made a coaster. With 20-20 hindsight, I can see why that didn't work, 
but I still don't know how I made the first DVD!

Is there something I've missed, or am I on the right track in 
considering the DVD corrupted?

> one of the BSDs? What do you gain, what do you lose, and do you still get
> comparable performance?

Because Linux has current and updated software from this century?

SCO has never been a good choice.  They have always been the most 
expensive option out there for what you get.  Now that they have even 
bigger lawyer bills than what they pay their developers, it is even worse.

AIX works, but it has limited and crufty tools.  You can get packages from 
IBM for most of the Linux tools, but they are from Redhat 7.x and are not 
current or patched regularly.  Not certain why anyone would want to run 
AIX unless they had an app that demanded it or special hardware needs.

HP-UX and I have never gotten along.  Less said the better.

Until reciently Solaris has shipped old outdated versions of tools, did 
not ship with a C compiler and took forever for security patches.  They 
are getting better.  The Sun hardware allows some useful remote debugging 
posibilities I have heard.  Never had to use them.

It really depends on the hardware you want to use, the level of 
handholding you need from a vendor and the speed of security patches. 
Linux provides all those these days. Not certain what the support for the 
BSDs are like anymore.  (OS X and BSDi are the only commercial BSDs I have 
used.)

I prefer Linux because I can get more than enough software for it and it 
does what I want.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Jul 14 16:23:50 2006
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2006 16:23:50 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] I wonder if I can find an opinion here...
In-Reply-To: <200607141520.45487.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200607141520.45487.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <2932-68420@sneakemail.com>

On 7/14/06, Carla Schroder carla-at-bratgrrl.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I know absolutely nothing about Unixes like AIX, SCO Unix, HP-UX, Solaris, and
> all those good ole systems. So I seek the wisdom of the collective. Why would
> a hypothetical admin of a nice stout Unix system want to migrate to Linux or
> one of the BSDs? What do you gain, what do you lose, and do you still get
> comparable performance?

Carla:

Here's my take on it:

GAIN:
  + lower cost per unit of performance
  + easier hiring (lots of linux folks around)
  + consistent OS from desktop to server
  + avoid licensing headaches

LOSE:
  + app certification only on UNIX/Windows (this is becoming less common)
  + serial console that always works
  + proprietary UNIX iron hardware diagnostics
  + single-image scaling to large numbers of CPUs
  + Enterprise-quality OS support from vendor

I'm sure the "lose" list is likely to start a lively discussion, so
let me explain a bit...

The OS is there to run an application.  The applications are often
purchased, and if the vendor doesn't support Linux, it's removed from
the table.  The same is true if they don't support a particular UNIX.
Fortunately, this is becoming increasingly rare as Linux gains
popularity.

Perhaps a minor nit, but as a sysadmin if there's problems on a server
and I can't get to the console, it's bad.  I need some way to get in
to diagnose a LAN or NIC problem if the box is off the network.  Linux
servers make this more difficult since unlike dedicated/proprietary
hardware they can't be assured at always having a serial console
available that's not used by a mouse, modem, or other device so most
distros don't enable the serial console by default.  In addition, very
few servers for Linux have a BIOS-over-serial-port available.
Expensive remote-VGA-console cards intended for Windows work
reasonably well but can be slow over WAN links.

The hardware diags built into dedicated UNIX servers can be impressive
when compared to those in the x86 world.  For example, the exact DIMM
that's tossing the single-bit errors can be identified.  This sure
beats DIMM-swapping between memtest86+ runs!  If you need to take a
memory dump for debugging purposes, on some servers you just push a
button and it dumps.  The ability to achieve tight integration between
the hardware and the OS can be an advantage-- albeit a costly one.

Many UNIX systems routinely run applications on servers with over a
hundred processors.  Linux isn't there yet.  Clustering is not always
a viable alternative, either.

Lastly, my support experiences with RedHat have been awful.  I get
better help from the 'net at large.  The proprietary OS vendors use
their support as a selling point and it's generally good, and in some
cases can be excellent.

  -- Steve

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Jul 14 18:06:47 2006
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2006 18:06:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] I wonder if I can find an opinion here...
In-Reply-To: <2932-68420@sneakemail.com>
References: <200607141520.45487.carla@bratgrrl.com> <2932-68420@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1152925608.17148.81.camel@spartacus.nakedape.priv>

On Fri, 2006-07-14 at 16:23 -0700, Steve Bonds wrote:

Here are my additions, but they mostly apply to Solaris (8 and older)
and AIX; I don't have much experience with OS X, HP-UX and just a
modicum of experience with ancient versions of SCO OpenServer, Data
General's DG-UX, NeXTSTEP, BSDi's BSD/OS, Irix.

> GAIN:
>   + lower cost per unit of performance
>   + easier hiring (lots of linux folks around)
>   + consistent OS from desktop to server
>   + avoid licensing headaches

 + Great platform for developing (or developing with) and deploying 
   open source applications, languages.

   * Solaris is probably much better these days with the work of the 
     Blastwave (http://www.blastwave.org/).  With SFW it was hit or 
     miss.
   * AIX, even with AIX Toolbox (http://sf.net/projects/aixtoolbox), 
     sucks.
   * Most modern Linux distributions have almost all the applications 
     you want readily available, either directly from the distributor 
     or from a 3rd party (like RPMforge).
   * Most applications are developed first on Linux and then ported.  
     Some are developed on *BSD and ported, but they're usually ported 
     much more quickly and more often.
   * (Nearly) guaranteed to have access to the compiler that built the 
     rest of the system, so building applications that use libraries 
     that are sensitive compiler maker and version is less painful 
     (think OpenSSL, Perl modules).

 + Sane patch and package management (well, except for SUSE).  This 
   should be both here and in the previous section.  When I don't have 
   a package already available, I can build it and without too much 
   suffering, penance and ritual sacrifice.  AIX at least supports RPM, 
   but it's an ancient version.  Good luck using a network-installer    
   like apt or yum.  (Well, AIX has NIM, which is kinda okay.  It's 
   also kinda shitty.)  It's also generally possible to update a Linux 
   system without rebooting; userland updates aren't closely tied to 
   kernel updates.  Not so with AIX or Solaris generally.

 + Modern, flexible userland.  At one time I thought I should 
   discipline myself to using ksh with vi mode, but I've since realized 
   that my life is too short and my typing too bad.

   * The proprietary UNIX systems lack a lot of things that seem 
     pretty basic in Linux systems--log rotation, 
     who's-got-that-port-open (netstat/lsof), vim, GNU utilities, 
     working top, tcpdump on localhost (couldn't do that on Solaris).

 + Depending on what system you get, the ability to replace a failed 
   piece of hardware within an hour or two.

 + Active, vibrant communities of users in a myriad of 
   channels--mailing lists, web sites, IRC, IM (anyone else tried Qunu 
   yet?), Usenet.  There's an AIX channel on Freenode and an okay 
   newsgroup; Solaris has a more active IRC channel and a few more 
   lists, but it's still paltry.

 + Periodicals.  Oh, SysAdmin is okay, I guess, but I have yet to find 
   either web or paper periodicals as good as LWN, LJ, LG, and the 
   myraid of other newsblogs like linux.com, slashdot, etc.  There used 
   to be UNIX Review, which became Server/Workstation Something, then 
   disappeared.  There used to be AIXpert, which ultimately became a 
   column in UNIX Review, and went down with it.  I guess there's an 
   AIX journal printed by the same people that print the IBM zSeries 
   mainframe journal I see a few people around the office, but I'm 
   prejudiced that a mainframe publisher can really speak UNIX.

 + Sane, sensible defaults.  I guess there's a lot more concern for 
   legacy with proprietary UNIX systems, which explains why the default 
   syslog configurations for AIX and Solaris are everywhere.  /var/adm, 
   WTF??  The FHS (nee FSSTND) is really wonderful and I wish 
   proprietary vendors would get on board.

 + Sane configuration and init system.  There are some nice things 
   about the ODM in AIX (it's a configuration database, not to be 
   compared with the Windows registry), but most SysV systems are 
   lame.  rc.config is better than that, and that kinda sucks too.  The 
   SRC in AIX is kinda nice (it's a system starter like DJB's   
   daemontools) and I hear there's something nice in Solaris 10.  But 
   the init scripts they do have, when they have them, look like they 
   were written by lazy interns.

I could probably go on, but it's Friday evening and I've got things to
do.

> LOSE:
>   + app certification only on UNIX/Windows (this is becoming less common)
>   + serial console that always works
>   + proprietary UNIX iron hardware diagnostics
>   + single-image scaling to large numbers of CPUs
>   + Enterprise-quality OS support from vendor

> The hardware diags built into dedicated UNIX servers can be impressive
> when compared to those in the x86 world.  For example, the exact DIMM
> that's tossing the single-bit errors can be identified.  This sure
> beats DIMM-swapping between memtest86+ runs!  If you need to take a
> memory dump for debugging purposes, on some servers you just push a
> button and it dumps.  The ability to achieve tight integration between
> the hardware and the OS can be an advantage-- albeit a costly one.

Hm, a lot of the depends on who's making the PC.  The expensive big iron
from the proprietary monoliths have a lot of the same capabilities.  I
used to be a lot more impressed with it than I am now.  The higher-end
stuff has hot-swappable CPUs, DIMMs, etc.

I'm especially unimpressed with the failure rate of absurdly expensive
hardware.  For that matter, I'm unimpressed with the failure rate of
their OSes too--I managed to kill AIX the other day with a simple
software installation.

> Many UNIX systems routinely run applications on servers with over a
> hundred processors.  Linux isn't there yet.  Clustering is not always
> a viable alternative, either.

Other than the old Cray vector machines, I don't think even the
highest-end UNIX hardware goes to a hundred--the Sun Fire E25k goes to
72 CPUs, with something like hyperthreading to make 144.

http://www.sun.com/servers/highend/sunfire_e25k/index.jsp

The p5 595 only goes to 64 cores, plus 2x Symmetric Multithreading:

http://www-03.ibm.com/servers/eserver/pseries/hardware/highend/595.html

Sure, there are bigger than PCs; the biggest xSeries 4 CPU, which is 8
cores (+ 2 hyperthreading)

But in most cases, at least with the IBM pSeries systems I use, boxes
that big are used to make partitions of smaller hosts--the biggest LPAR
in use is 4 dedicated CPUs.  The problem is that a lot of workloads
still don't scale across lots and lots of CPUs as one might like.

Sure, I get nervous hearing about people using 32GB of memory in a PC
running Linux; unless I had a lot of support and wasn't fighting a
I'll-show-you-Linux-on-a-PC-can-be-just-as-good fight, I wouldn't try
it.  

For running huge databases and workloads like that, a pSeries or Sun
running their respective OSes is probably a good choice.  But front-end
and middle-tier application layers?  Much better on Linux; these tend to
cluster or distribute well.

> Lastly, my support experiences with RedHat have been awful.  I get
> better help from the 'net at large.  The proprietary OS vendors use
> their support as a selling point and it's generally good, and in some
> cases can be excellent.

There are few things in the world I'd like to do less than calling
technical support, waiting on hold, hunting around for the right
customer or license number, explaining my problem to half a dozen people
over the telephone, most of whom just route me to someone else, never
explain the details about went wrong, rarely communicate back to
engineering (esp w/stuff that's not system-critical, like the fact that
their C headers are brain damaged and #define vaguely common words like
'open') and in almost all support cases I've seen, they were solved by a
hardware replacement, if I didn't solve it myself.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
Naked Ape Consulting, Ltd. <http://nakedape.cc>

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri Jul 14 18:16:03 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2006 18:16:03 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] web forum software
In-Reply-To: <20060714232727.CC4634615@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200607150116.k6F1G3hN023346@m5p.com>

>From: "Michael M." <nixlists at writemoore.net>
> A blog I've been reading, BikePortland.org, has a public forum component 
> that has been hit by spammers.  Jonathan Maus, the guy who runs the site 
> is looking to replace the forum software with vBulletin, which he says 
> is $85 for a one-year license.  You can read his post about it here:
> 
> http://bikeportland.org/2006/07/13/help-me-fix-the-forums/
> 
> I was just wondering if anyone knows of any free (as in beer) 
> open-source forum software that might be appropriate and has good 
> security options.  Unfortunately, he doesn't say in his post what 
> software he was using, just that it was free, but I gather from the 
> comments to the post that it was phpBB.  Someone else recommended 
> bbpress.  JM seems kinda set on vBulletin, though he appears to be open 
> to suggestions.  Anyone have any?

Spam came to Usenet and at first it wasn't too big and people deleted it.

Then it became largish and people installed basic filters. Some groups
moved to web-based bulliten boards to escape the spam.

The spammers responded with measures that bypassed the filters.

The e-mail game of whack-a-mole ensued which continues. The web-based
systems sat back and grinned thinking because they didn't use SMTP.

The spammers kept the game of e-mail whack-a-mole going. They noticed the
motion towards web-based bulliten boards and responded.

Now it is clear for all to see that aside from pissing folks off who
thought Usenet was pretty effective, that web-based boards don't avoid
the spammers.

Moving to another system will merely continue the game of whack-a-mole.
If that is the only reason, then don't bother, they'll be back and you'll
of annoyed some of your fans. Porting Spam Assassin to work with other
things would be a partial solution, though it is still merely
whack-a-mole. The irony is that it was the variety that made web-based
systems take a long time to attack, yet now this variety makes a general
filtering a lot more difficult.

On Fri, Jul 14, 2006 at 05:01:01PM -0700, alan wrote:
> 
> Figures my laptop would be in warrenty repair the weekend of the clinic as

My wife's Thinkpad T30 got a non-warranty repair this morning - it was
making gnarly sounds and freezing occasionally.  Since it is out of
warranty, and I know how to disassemble a T30 down to the mainboard,
I removed lots of screws and cleaned it out. 

Little dust bunnies everywhere - the fan above the CPU was coated with
dust, and the input and output channel was mostly clogged.  The CPU
was probably overheating.  The globs of dust added up to about the
size of a grape.  I didn't pull the main board all the way - there
is probably more dust underneath - but at least there is clear airflow
through the main components.

The unit works a lot better now.

References: <20060714165749.c31a588f.johnxj@comcast.net>	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0607141700150.25473@blackbox.fnordora.org>	<20060715015029.GC25564@gate.kl-ic.com>

Message-ID: <44B8752E.1090509@comcast.net>

A GREAT alternative to the compressed air cans is to go to Harbor 
Freight Tools (or harborfreight.com) and get one of those cans that can 
be pressurized.  They are meant for spraying paint (think refillable 
spray paint can) BUT you can pump them up with a bike pump or compressor 
- are VERY portable, and even environmentally friendly (only air, no 
propellant!).

$10 for the can at Harbor Freight, bike pump free to $10 if you look around!

RP

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Sat Jul 15 01:06:32 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Sat, 15 Jul 2006 01:06:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Laptop dust bunnies
In-Reply-To: <44B8752E.1090509@comcast.net>
References: <20060714165749.c31a588f.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<1152940008.31663.16.camel@spartacus.nakedape.priv>
	<44B8752E.1090509@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <200607150106.32902.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from Renegade Penguin
# on Friday 14 July 2006 09:55 pm:

>They are meant for spraying paint (think refillable
>spray paint can) BUT you can pump them up with a bike pump or
> compressor - are VERY portable, and even environmentally friendly
> (only air, no propellant!).

The premium part of the canned air is that it has no dirt or moisture in 
it.  The other part is it's not air since liquid N2 is a bit harder to 
ship.  As for environmental friendliness, I'm guessing the cost/weight 
tradeoff of using a fluorocarbon instead of CO2 was just too good to 
pass up (or is there some other reason not to use CO2 like that 
easy-to-compress-to-a-liquid-state near-room-temperature-range boiling 
point of refrigerants?)

A cylinder of N2 or CO/2 from NAPA might be better than a compressor for 
refilling your little spray can.  Bit of a steep investment for the 
cylinder (and hey -- spring for the little cart) if you only go through 
one a year, but blowing-out an entire data center on a $9.95 refill has 
got to be priceless.

--Eric

Well, sure.  But it'll allow abritrary code to run as root, so if you've

know whether or not their systems are secure and those who don't, well, 
probably aren't secure.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jul 14 18:40:27 2006
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)
Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2006 18:40:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Color Computer...
Message-ID: <1152927627.44b8478b74f9b@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

Why can't the Tandy Color Computer 3 run Linux?  I found a company,
http://cloud9tech.com/, that refurbishes and upgrades color computers.
For those of us who have 256k 30 pin simms lying around for example,
they have a part that allows 2 of them to be installed in a Color
Computer 3.  I don't know why they don't allow installation of 4 to 8
simm chips.  2 megs might be nice, especially if you could run a 
ramdrive on a color computer since disk and tape access is so slow.

What I've heard, the color computer died because the GIME chip was 
engineered in such a way that it would have to be completely redone
costing too much.  Other theories are that the Tandy 1000 was 
supposed to be better than the color computer, so Tandy purposely 
gave the coco 3 less by dropping, for example, 256 color support.

Apparently, the 68B09E has on chip memory management capabilities.  I've
run into an OS-9 replacement called Nitros9 that some sites on the
Internet compare to UNIX.

I wrote my first programs on a color and still feel it's a good platform
to explore with.  Computers are so complicated now, it seems that the
fun has been lost.

What would a color computer be like today if the line hadn't ceased in 1989?  
Color computers didn't even have real time clocks in them, I wonder what did
between 1970 and 1989?  When did the first 386 hit the consumer market?

I still have a color computer 3, but noone sells 5.25" 360k media anymore
and my disks are going bad.

It sure would be awesome if I could get a rom pack version of Power Stones
of Ard II to replace my bad disk.  The rom pak could possibly have flash
chips in it so the game to be saved.

The color computer never was Z80 based, why on earth was the coco 2 called
the TRS 80 in the first place?

Is it true that the 6809 was the predecessor to the 68000 processors that
the early Macs were based on?  Were there any other spin offs?  Were there
any further attempts to create a successor to the color computer 3 after 
the Tomcat and MMI flopped?

How much longer will old color computers be around.  Is the design lost?
Could someone build one from scratch today?  It has probably been 14 years
since a color computer has been manufactured.  In 6 more don't the copyrights
Tandy had expire?  I've heard suggestions that a CoCo 4 capable of running
at 200 mHz could be built today that would be downward compatible.  If 
someone were to attempt to do this though, the machine should probably 
be 32 bit so it can run Linux.  How could you make a 32 bit color computer
that is compatible with what came before?

-------------------------------------------------

Though I don't recommend anyone use PHP, ever(, ever), Pear is what
you're looking for I think.  It's a bit More than just a database
abstraction system, but its database layer behaves very much like perl's
DBI.pm.

http://pear.php.net/index.php

On Sat, 15 Jul 2006, Dave Houston wrote:

> Though I don't recommend anyone use PHP, ever(, ever), Pear is what you're
> looking for I think.  It's a bit More than just a database abstraction
> system, but its database layer behaves very much like perl's DBI.pm.

Dave,

   When I look at Zend's web site I see that they don't recommend it as an
application development language, either. A single web page, yes; more than
that, no.

   Regardless, the developers of XRMS <http://xrms.sourceforge.net/> decided
on using php, and that's the way it is. But, they (like SugarCRM) hardwired
it for MySQL only. Late last year, someone else started trying to make it
work with PostgreSQL-8.x, and I've taken up where he left off. I've found
and fixed the bugs that generated when the install.php script was run, but
there are still a lot of error that keep it from running.

   My Google search turned up ADOdb which is a large php class that provides
dbms abstration for a whole slew of back ends -- including Microsoft's and
Oracle. I've asked the developer who's been doing some postgres-related work
why it would not be more better to devote development time on integrating
something like ADOdb than trying to find all the code that must be changed
somehow to work with both mysql and postgres. Reinventing the wheel type of
effort.

   From what I've seen, XRMS is the client resource management/sales lead
administration application that I want and need. I tried SugarCRM and just
did not like it. Seems to be that Pear or ADOdb would allow a solution
faster and with less effort than what is now being done. I'll pass on the
pear info.

Thanks,

Rich

From creswick at gmail.com  Sat Jul 15 15:01:06 2006
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Sat, 15 Jul 2006 15:01:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Color Computer...
In-Reply-To: <1152927627.44b8478b74f9b@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <1152927627.44b8478b74f9b@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <c834ec80607151501m6016bd7j84e4d3a27b55ca9f@mail.gmail.com>

On 7/14/06, plug_0 at robinson-west.com <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
> part that allows 2 of them to be installed in a Color
> Computer 3.  I don't know why they don't allow installation of 4 to 8
> simm chips.  2 megs might be nice, especially if you could run a
> ramdrive on a color computer since disk and tape access is so slow.

It's probably not capable of addressing more than 2megs or ram.  If
you've only got 8 bits to store memory addresses in, then you just
can't "see" more than 2^8 * (wordsize) bits.

I'm no expert in hardware design, but that's the basic principle of
the thing... I'm sure other people can chime in with specifics and /
or corrections :)

--Rogan

fully, ADOdb does not do all the translating required for each dbms'
ideosyncracies. That's why we keep seeing errors despite their incorporation
of ADOdb.

   Now, I thought the purpose of such middleware was to let one write sql
statements in any supported language, and it would translate them to the
appropriate syntax for the database backend. Returned tuples would also be
translated to a neutral syntax that the application could display. Having
used neither PHP nor ADOdb for anything I've written, I can only pass on
what I've been told.

Rich

On Sat, 15 Jul 2006, Rich Shepard wrote:

>> It says it works with PostgreSQL.. you've tried and it doesn't?

Brent,

   Here's what I just learned: ADOdb will translate record insertions and
retrievals, but not SELECT statements. It is in those that the errors come
up. It can be a major PITA if one dbms supports full outer joins and another
does not, for example.

From dave.houston at gmail.com  Sat Jul 15 19:53:43 2006

	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0607151752410.6535@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1153018423.17841.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I think you've just hit on why developers pick one database and stick
with it.  There's just too much variance between the feature sets to get
any sort of real performance when you using the lowest common
denominator.  

>From my experience with DBI.pm, you /can/ write something that will work
everywhere, but you're going to do it slowly and poorly.

A design tip that I've found useful:  Make your application look
something like:

[app]<----[AppDB]<----[ADOdb]<----(database)

Where 'AppDB' is some class you spent time writing that has very, very
custom function calls to handle your app's needs, and stay the bloody
hell away from using direct SQL inside your application.

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Sat Jul 15 19:36:41 2006
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Sat, 15 Jul 2006 20:36:41 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Command line tools to troubleshoot Samba
In-Reply-To: <20060715192044.b115a5df.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060715192044.b115a5df.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607152022370.20754@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>

First thing to do is to establish functonal network connectivity on both
machines.  The connections between the 2 smaba endpoints must be deemed
good first, before delving into samba config files.  If it worked when
the machines' network connections were functioning, and it doesn't work
now that at least one of the machines can't talk, my gut feeling tells
me that this is your real problem (unless you hosed your samba config
while clicking around in the death GUI, trying to make something happen).

It is not good to assume things when troubleshooting.  One needs to
know: does the linux box's network connectivity function normally in all
respects other than conversations with the windows box?  Can the linux
box get to the internet, and can it get an IP address from your DHCP
server?  Can the linux box ping your router?  (I'm making assumptions
about your network - shame on me.)

If I had to make a call on the information provided thus far, I'd say
your windows box is 100% the problem.  Its network connectivity died.
Why is uncertain.  Start with hardware, then get a physical link, then
get an IP address, then check the routing table (windows has a route
command too), then ping, then get a web page, then nmap the windows box
from the linux box and look for samba ports:

netbios-ns      137/tcp             # NETBIOS Name Service
netbios-ns      137/udp
netbios-dgm     138/tcp             # NETBIOS Datagram Service
netbios-dgm     138/udp
netbios-ssn     139/tcp             # NETBIOS Session Service
netbios-ssn     139/udp
microsoft-ds    445/tcp             Microsoft-DS
microsoft-ds    445/udp             Microsoft-DS

At least some of these ports should be open.  Not all of them, though.
These are just all the relevant entries from the /etc/services file.  I
don't have a windows box to ping, or I'd give you the exact list of
ports to expect.

Then I'd use ethereal on the linux box to watch BROWSER packets.  the
windows box will squawk every few minutes if functioning "correctly".

Carlos Konstanski

On Sat, 2006-07-15 at 14:56 -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:

>    From what I've seen, XRMS is the client resource management/sales lead
> administration application that I want and need. I tried SugarCRM and just
> did not like it. Seems to be that Pear or ADOdb would allow a solution
> faster and with less effort than what is now being done. I'll pass on the
> pear info.

You've been doing Python lately, haven't you?  You might look into
Roundup (http://roundup.sourceforge.net/).  At its most basic, a request
tracker, but it's very adaptable, as you can see from the list of
applications it's been used for on the first page and the concepts
behind request trackers and CRM apps have a lot of parity.  Plus, it's
already got an abstracted DB backend w/Postgres support and it's written
in a language (I think) you understand.

In-Reply-To: <c29537840607152315o5f3d9983kf4e3effc1bb72627@mail.gmail.com>

On Sat, 15 Jul 2006 23:15:54 -0700
"Jason R. Martin" <nsxfreddy at gmail.com> dijo:

> > Thanks for the suggestions. Barring some additional brilliant insight,
> > I'm going to wait until someone on the Ubuntu forums figures out what
> > is going on.
> 
> There's one flaw in your logic:
> 
> "Today neither can ping each other, not even using ip address."
> 
> Before screwing around any more with Samba, I would suggest following
> Carlos' advice, and fix your networking.  Samba has nothing to do with
> ping.  Once that is working, then you can worry about the Samba
> install errors.  Hopefully you saved a good copy of your working Samba
> configuration.

Previous to the current difficulty, ping always worked. However, I
misstated something when I said "neither can ping each other." At the
moment it works from the Linux laptop to anyplace on the internet
(e.g., the Comcast DNS server addresses), it works to my two big HP
Laserjets via home ethernet (Jetdirect cards), but doesn't work from
the Linux laptop to the Windows desktop. However, the Windows desktop
can ping everything, including the Linux laptop. So evidently the only
time ping does not work is when the Linux laptop (192.168.1.102) tries
to ping the Windows desktop (192,168.1.100).

In the meantime, someone on the Ubuntu forums pointed out that the
error we are getting when removing and installing Samba has to do with
some links in /etc/rc.X that are incorrect. The poster pointed out that
doing a "remove completely" from Synaptic before doing an install will
clear those out. (Same as --purge.) I tried it and it worked. No more
error messages on removing and installing Samba. Nevertheless, I still
can't see anything on the Windows desktop, nor do I get a ping response
from it.

After much poking around on the Windows desktop, this is what I found:
	IP address: 192.168.1.100
	IP subnet: 255.255.255.0
	Default IP gateway: 192.168.1.1
	DHCP enabled: True
	MAC address: 00:40:F4:60:73:7A

Doing ifconfig on the Linux laptop gives me:
jjj at Devil5:~$ ifconfig
eth0      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 00:0F:B0:03:03:86
          inet addr:192.168.1.102  Bcast:192.168.1.255
Mask:255.255.255.0 inet6 addr: fe80::20f:b0ff:fe03:386/64 Scope:Link
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1492  Metric:1
          RX packets:79679 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:42866 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:1000
          RX bytes:104544932 (99.7 MiB)  TX bytes:3290806 (3.1 MiB)
          Interrupt:185 Base address:0x6800
lo        Link encap:Local Loopback
          inet addr:127.0.0.1  Mask:255.0.0.0
          inet6 addr: ::1/128 Scope:Host
          UP LOOPBACK RUNNING  MTU:16436  Metric:1
          RX packets:14068 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:14068 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:0
          RX bytes:610620 (596.3 KiB)  TX bytes:610620 (596.3 KiB)

I don't understand why the Linux computer can ping the whole world,
except the Windows desktop.

I've also discovered something else on the Windows desktop. The network
card is a Realtek RTL8139(A). Device Manager shows it as working fine.
However, next to it are two additional "devices": Packet Scheduler
Miniport #6 Realtek RTL8139(A) PCI Fast Ethernet Adapter Realtek RTL8139
(A) PCI Fast Ethernet Adapter - Packet Scheduler Miniport The two
packet scheduler miniport entries have a yellow ! next to them, and
their properties indicate that they are not functioning properly
because of driver issues. I tried various things to fix them, but
nothing worked.

Then I remembered that I had a second bare-bones installation of
Windows 2000 on the desktop, to be used as a rescue installation. I
shut down and booted the bare-bones installation. Its Device Manager
listed just the Realtek card, no references to any packet scheduler
miniport things. And this installation was still able to ping and go to
the internet, etc., so evidently those two miniport things are not
essential. Before shutting down the rescue installation I tried pinging
it from the Linux laptop, but still no joy. I also tried looking at
Network Places with Nautilus, but it still sees just "Windows Network,"
but nothing inside the network.

Then I rebooted to the usual Windows desktop installation. I opened
Device Manager and disabled the two miniport things. That required
restarting, so I did so. When it came back up the Linux laptop still
couldn't see the Windows desktop or ping it. But Device Manager now
showed: Packet Scheduler Miniport #5 Packet Scheduler Miniport #6
Realtek RTL8139(A) PCI Fast Ethernet Adapter Very strange. And neither
of the miniport things was disabled, even though I had definitely
disabled them.

I still think the problem is somewhere on the Linux laptop. But it's
time for the Clinic, so that will have to wait until later.

Check the Windows firewall -- I'm pretty sure in that it disabled
incoming ICMP by default.  Not that this will clear up your samba
problem.  

If I recall correctly (and I don't), you get to the windows firewall
configuration by doing a right-click-properties on the network
connection, "Advanced" and keep clicking until you find something that
looks like a firewall.

It's also possible that the routing tables on either the linux or
windows machine is off, though, with your setup (.1's and .255's) it's
pretty hard to screw up..

On XP it's 'ROUTE PRINT', on 'nix it's '/sbin/route -n' ...

Message-ID: <20060716183858.b1e2570a.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Sun, 16 Jul 2006 12:09:49 -0700
John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> dijo:

> I don't understand why the Linux computer can ping the whole world,
> except the Windows desktop.
> ...
> I still think the problem is somewhere on the Linux laptop. But it's
> time for the Clinic, so that will have to wait until later.

OK, I have installed a fresh Ubuntu on another partition on the laptop.
It sees the Windows desktop just fine, the same as my main installation
of Ubuntu used to do. Conclusion: The Windows computer is not the
problem; something in my main Ubuntu installation is hosed.

And I just found out what it is: Firestarter. Yup, it was the Linux
firewall, not the Windows firewall. I went through System >
Administration and noticed that I had not checked out Firestarter yet.
I did so, it popped up a window, and there was a button to disable the
firewall. I clicked on it, then went to Places > Network Servers and
voil?!

So now I have to figure out how to keep Firestarter doing its thing
while still letting me see the Windows desktop. That will be another
adventure, I am sure. But at least now I found the problem.

Thanks to all for your inputs.

On Mon, 17 Jul 2006, Alan Olsen wrote:

> Remember the conversation about remote administration and being able 
> to see the boot process?
> 
> I wish I had that now.

Very few PC makers make it possible (much less easy) to push 
BIOS-level I/O to a serial port. HP/Compaq does; newer Opteron boards 
from SuperMicro do. PV Weasel cards will do the trick, but at $300 per 
card, they don't really provide a scalable solution.

Sigh. SPARCs and Alphas have had native serial console support since, 
what, 1990? It's not cutting-edge computer science. The boot-time 
logic is simple: "Hmm ... there's no keyboard attached to me; better 
spew out the serial port instead."

> How much longer will old color computers be around.  Is the design lost?

> Tandy had expire?  I've heard suggestions that a CoCo 4 capable of running
> at 200 mHz could be built today that would be downward compatible.  If

You're thinking of patents, which last 20 years.  Copyright, thanks to 
the Sonny Bono CETA passed by Congress, last life + 75 years or a flat 
95 years for corporate-created works.  Any copyrights created by Tandy 
14 years ago will be in force until 2087.  And that's only if Congress 
doesn't extend copyright terms again, which our Congresscritters have 
been all too willing to do.  They get handsomely rewarded by the 
entertainment and software lobbies for their cooperation.

On 7/17/06, Bruce Kilpatrick <bakilpatrick at verizon.net> wrote:
> I do not want to revert to the 386 kernel and am wondering how to tell
> the program not to install the patch, ever...or if I want to install it

I think you still have the -386 kernel installed, so it wants to keep
it updated (even if you're using the 686-smp one). You probably want
to just uninstall the 386 kernel image altogether.

From ron at Opus1.COM  Mon Jul 17 21:05:47 2006
From: ron at Opus1.COM (Ronald Chmara)
Date: Mon, 17 Jul 2006 21:05:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] My mail server is down for the moment...
In-Reply-To: <55cf303a0607171252w6bc32e00sf27d5aa291c4160a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <55cf303a0607171252w6bc32e00sf27d5aa291c4160a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <a1d0f63673095fc434a99deda0e338b3@opus1.com>

On Jul 17, 2006, at 12:52 PM, Alan Olsen wrote:
> Remember the conversation about remote administration and being able 
> to see
> the boot process?
> I wish I had that now.
> I updated my mail server to the latest kernel for FC4 and rebooted.
> It did not come back up.  I won't know why until tonight, when I can 
> look at
> the console.
> Sigh.
> Well, at least I am supposed to get my laptop back today.  Hopefully 
> they
> fixed it.  (And not like a vet fixes a cat.)

I know it's not much help now, but I have a *very* small list of things 
I *never* do remotely:
1. kernel upgrades (if it bonks on the BIOS level, no remote daemon can 
save you... the only fix would be a magic box that tunneled raw VGA 
output, raw PS2/USB input, etc. over TCP/IP... is there such a beast?)
2. RAID juggling (if /boot is on a SCSI RAID 5, for example)
3. For that matter, anything SCSI. Requires waaaay too many goat 
sacrifices when *at* the console to even consider doing remotely. (Or, 
alternately, really good high end cables and terminators, which I 
*never* seem to see IRL.)
4. Any crypto library changes, or pam changes, if my sole admin access 
is ssh. (Want to know how to make an sshd session work when the daemon 
dies because libraries have changed? So do I.)
5. ifconfig changes (without a crond/atd backup script to restore 
settings) on single NIC machines.
6. For that matter, ipchains/iptables/ipfw changes (without a crond/atd 
backup script to restore settings) on even multi-NIC machines.

Anybody else have warnings to add to the historical pool of "Ooops", so 
future admin folks can spend less time pounding their heads mercilessly 
into keyboards?

-Bop
--
Ronald Chmara
4245 NE Alberta Ct.
Portland, OR 97218
503-282-1370



From plancashire at ci.portland.or.us  Tue Jul 18 09:26:56 2006
From: plancashire at ci.portland.or.us (Lancashire, Pete)
Date: Tue, 18 Jul 2006 09:26:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] I wonder if I can find an opinion here...
Message-ID: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDC5A@cityemail.bit.city>

hmm I'll toss my 30 yrs in :)

> AIX works, but it has limited and crufty tools.  You can get 
> packages from 
> IBM for most of the Linux tools, but they are from Redhat 7.x 
> and are not 
> current or patched regularly.  Not certain why anyone would 
> want to run 
> AIX unless they had an app that demanded it or special hardware needs.

I totally agree on this one. But one has to remember, today purchases
on this type of server are not usually made on technical merits, if any
technology is there, it is usually covered in so much gloss (as in glossies
a slang for marketing/advertising paper) that you need a chisel to
get to the dead tree material. IBM got to be IBM on their marketing and
sales skills,
and still do. They have tons of technology such as the pSeries but if you
look at the performance/cost matrix then add AIX, it is at my pc opinion
sad, AIX could have been something great. But knowing a couple (ex) IBM
engineering VP's, they constantly were under the eye of Armonk not to
steal sales form the X and I series, or for us old timers AS/400 and 390's.
They say the power-5 has so much going for it, such as the ability to
monitor internal registers, etc, but to get to see anything performance
wise you have to shell out $1000's and that is plural just to look.
Add that to get C, C++ and a dev environment will set you back about $4K.
There is only one third party OSS software source and it is getting really
bad, UCSD. Last time I had something that didn't work, their reply was
we just compile it, we don't use it. If IBM did not give them hardware
for basically free, my call is they would vanish as fast as Toronto did.
As to the hardware
to get a say 4 way server reasonable loaded say with 16 GB RAM, etc, will
set you back close to $60-100K, and that 4 way is not 4 CPU's, it is
a 4 Core CPU. Again, marketing. That $20K box they advertise is a scam
period.

> SCO has never been a good choice.  They have always been the most 
> expensive option out there for what you get.  Now that they have even 
> bigger lawyer bills than what they pay their developers, it 
> is even worse.

1000% agree, that's why you saw it so much in gov't locations,
their only technology was in the quality of the sales presentations,
and the type of cloth the suits were made out of. The best is IBM.


> HP-UX and I have never gotten along.  Less said the better.

Never used it, to me HP's fame was the ability to sell a complete
package, and the package worked. A good example is 1/2 of all
credit unions were HP, and it worked. Nothing to do with HPUX.


> Until recently Solaris has shipped old outdated versions of 
> tools, did 
> not ship with a C compiler and took forever for security 
> patches.  They 
> are getting better.  The Sun hardware allows some useful 
> remote debugging 
> possibilities I have heard.  Never had to use them.

Here's the one I will disagree on. They had good tools but
where expensive, and the UI for the tools were mostly command
line. On packages they unofficially support SFW (SunFreeWare),
think of a fedora repository but for Solaris. When I admin'd
a shop with Sun/Solaris I had no trouble getting
the latest FOSS from SFW. 
As with AIX, the C/C++ compiler was not free, but not like
AIX, gcc was available from SFW and it worked. Sun's C got
you more performance but not much more unless you were doing some
fancy SMP tricks. More the libraries then the compiler itself.
Check out Dtrace .. it is totally awesome. Their Fortran was
very good.
As to hardware, if your application can really make use of
SMP and more importantly fine grained threading, you cant
beat something like the 890, especially if it has 64 GB of RAM.
Not everything can be run on a 1,000 chickens (*).
I was part of a group in 1995 that tried to convince Sun to

Yup. Lets see... they've tried:

b) a beastly (in the best and worst ways) AIX setup (circa "Apple

makes me gnash my teeth, and the darned things took up *insane* amounts 
of physical space.
c) and now they're on to OSX's Mach/Darwin/BSD/NextOS/Gnu stack, and 
their server line takes up one rack height unit, but sounds like a 747 
and requires some severe rack *depth*.

It's almost as if Apple just had an aversion to using *nix variants that 
anybody else *liked*.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Jul 18 10:45:55 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 18 Jul 2006 10:45:55 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] I wonder if I can find an opinion here...
In-Reply-To: <44BD14FC.3060608@opus1.com>
References: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDC5A@cityemail.bit.city>
	<44BD14FC.3060608@opus1.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0607181020060.4953@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Tue, 18 Jul 2006, Ronald Chmara wrote:

> c) and now they're on to OSX's Mach/Darwin/BSD/NextOS/Gnu stack, and 
> their server line takes up one rack height unit, but sounds like a 
> 747 and requires some severe rack *depth*.
> 
> It's almost as if Apple just had an aversion to using *nix variants 
> that anybody else *liked*.

It's not *that* bad...

Just about any 1U server is loud; the form factor forces those tiny 
fans to spin so quickly. I've got Apples, Dells, Penguins, and others 
in the server room at work; they're all loud compared to an average 2U 
unit.

The PowerPC Xserve machines all have decent support for serial 
consoles; their Samba and OpenLDAP implementations work and play well 
with both Windows and Linux; and Apple has done a reasonable job of 
documenting the command-line equivalents of the GUI tools:

 * OS X 10.3.x:
   http://www.apple.com/server/pdfs/Command_Line.pdf

 * OS X 10.4.x:
   http://images.apple.com/server/pdfs/Command_Line_v10.4_2nd_Ed.pdf

I have three main beefs:

1. GUI Administration vs. ASCII Config Files

Apple's BSD underpinnings are mostly well-behaved. The hard part is 
getting the GUI to work and play well with ASCII config files. I like 
to keep configuration files in a Subversion repository and push into 
production via cfengine.

But ... the minute I open the administrative GUI for any given daemon, 
the GUI will parse and re-write the config file, often removing 
comments or directives it doesn't understand (even if the underlying 
daemon *does* understand them).

Then again, this isn't so much different from using GUI controls on 
Linux boxes. It's tough to mix and match administrative techniques.

2. Launch Manager

The hardest part for me to understand continues to be the launch 
manager. Apple's developers are trying to depart from both the BSD and 
System V init methods -- and I think they've got a ways to go before 
the system will mature.

That said, there have been rumblings in the Linux community about the 
shortcomings of the traditional init systems. Parallelization is a big 
topic, as are the increasing difficulties of getting daemons 
initialized in the correct order. The Gentoo rc-update system is 
another attempt to solve these problems in non-traditional ways.

3. Lack of Unified Package Management

Apple provides fairly timely updates for Unix utilities near the core 
of the system (httpd, smbd, etc.) -- but there's no vendor-approved, 
integrated way to add other *nix applications to the system.

You end up using fink, Portage, or DarwinPorts, all of which exist 
outside Apple's own package system. I've read rumors that Apple is 
addressing the problem, but so far it's just rumors.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

From m0gely at telestream.com  Tue Jul 18 15:16:32 2006

In-Reply-To: <a1d0f63673095fc434a99deda0e338b3@opus1.com>

	<a1d0f63673095fc434a99deda0e338b3@opus1.com>
Message-ID: <44BD5DC0.100@telestream.com>

Ronald Chmara wrote:

> I know it's not much help now, but I have a *very* small list of things 
> I *never* do remotely:
> 1. kernel upgrades (if it bonks on the BIOS level, no remote daemon can 
> save you... the only fix would be a magic box that tunneled raw VGA 
> output, raw PS2/USB input, etc. over TCP/IP... is there such a beast?)

It's called serial output.  There is no raw vga.  It's just text you're 
looking at.  Some BIOS's will have a setting for redirecting console 
output to a serial port.  If you're using a GUI then forget it.  This 
method is for command line only.  It also requires another computer next 
to it, or a remote console appliance.  You can watch the computer boot 
up from the beginning, even going into the BIOS to make changes.

management tools on OS X Server get better with each release, but

gradually ditching all their non-Apple server stuff (transition is  
nowhere near complet and they are Eating Their Own Dogfood. The  
complaints we all have are going to become very real to the folks  
within Apple and we will see a lot of our frustrations addressed.

At least, that's my hope.

Left one out

Tru64 DEC Alpha. This one to me had a lot going for it. Another
example of West vs. East. The WRL (leave that as a challenge)
guys came out with some very nice small boxen, the engineers
where very gung ho' about not only doing the best big boxes but
did some very nice "affordable" boxes.

Tru64 had great SMP, a lot of other performance features, and
the start of a good open source library/site. But then
Maynard (another test :) )got involved, started the DEC
(and other suit type vendors) vs. Sun (technology, stability,
birkenstocks, etc) wars.

A good friend of mine at WRL left DEC for Sun, and the way he
put it, everyone at WRL wanted to be on the other side of that
war.

On Wed, 19 Jul 2006, Lancashire, Pete wrote:

> A good friend of mine at WRL left DEC for Sun, and the way he put 
> it, everyone at WRL wanted to be on the other side of that war.

I know a guy who sold Alphas through the 90s and into 2001. From his 
POV, the writing was on the wall: the Alpha's performance lead was 
dropping steadily, DEC could no longer remain competitive charging 
premium prices on their smaller and mid-sized servers, GNU/Linux/*BSD 
were making Unix functionality a commodity, and DEC (then DEC/Compaq) 
needed to invest too much to maintain its ever-slimmer tech lead over 
the x86 crowd.

That, and (locally, at least) DEC/Compaq was *really* stingy with 
Tru64. When I was at OGI, we had a small-ish Alpha-based compute 
cluster. Their .edu sales staff came calling one day, and I 
practically begged for an eval copy. No dice. Feh!

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

> dropping steadily, DEC could no longer remain competitive charging 
> premium prices on their smaller and mid-sized servers, GNU/Linux/*BSD 
> were making Unix functionality a commodity, and DEC (then DEC/Compaq) 
> needed to invest too much to maintain its ever-slimmer tech lead over 
> the x86 crowd.
> 
> That, and (locally, at least) DEC/Compaq was *really* stingy with 
> Tru64. When I was at OGI, we had a small-ish Alpha-based compute 
> cluster. Their .edu sales staff came calling one day, and I 
> practically begged for an eval copy. No dice. Feh!

From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Wed Jul 19 11:13:37 2006
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2006 12:13:37 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] squirrelmail
In-Reply-To: <727fc2ee0607190958v12f506aav250ff11f956aa5d5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <727fc2ee0607190958v12f506aav250ff11f956aa5d5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191212370.23621@ns.pippiandcarlos.com>

The first readily apparent difference between you and him is the choice
of browser.  Now, IE (as an example of a steamy pile o' browser) requires
"http://" in front of a URL if it doesn't start with "www".  Maybe
safari is even worse, and requires the protocol at all times.

Can your friend ping "www.domain.com"?  Can he hit
"http://www.domain.com/squirrelmail" with lynx or wget?  Best to remove
variables from the equation when troubleshooting.

Do you have POP or IMAP running?  Can your friend hit it with pine?
Pine is good because you can send him a known good .pinerc file.  Either
it works, or it doesn't.  There is no ambiguity about the configuration.
You do not need to send him an openoffice doc with screenshots of kmail
account config, and hope he can follow it.

Any "Allow from" directives in your apache virtual host config that
would exclude your friend by IP address or other rule?

Is there an SSL cert involved?  Is he denying it, either consciously or
not?  Again, pine.

Carlos Konstanski

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 19 15:12:25 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2006 15:12:25 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Subversion question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191455080.11354@blackbox.fnordora.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191455080.11354@blackbox.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191508190.30309@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 19 Jul 2006, alan wrote:

> What I want is to see what happened in each step along the way.  So if
> there was a change to the file from revision 3 to revision 4, I want to
> see the diff of that, then if there is a change from 4 to 5, I want to see
> that change, etc.

> Suggestions?

Alan,

   According to the Subversion manual, "svn diff" shows you the specific
details of how a file changed over time.

   svn diff can:

   1) Examine local changes.
   2) Compare your working copy to the repository.
   3) Compare repository to repository.

   You want number 3, I believe:

   svn diff --revision x:y filename.c
   svn diff --revision y:z filename.c
etc.

Rich

From:

http://see.oneworld.net/article/view/136616/1/3260

Croatian Government Adopts Free Software Policy in State Administration

Tomislav Domes
18 July 2006

Last week, on July 12, the Government of Croatia adopted an official document 
titled Directions for Development and Use of Open Source Code Computer 
Programmes in Bodies and Institutions of State Administration. In the 
document, the Government accepts the responsibility to develop, prepare and 
procure open-source software solutions in the development of information 
systems of state administration bodies.

This policy is motivated, according to the document, by the fact that 
proprietary software leads to great dependence on suppliers, which can damage 
the market competition. Furthermore, open source programmes increase the 
transparency of administration?s work and free access to information. 
Ultimately, the document states that the use of open source based solutions 
will reduce the unjustified budget spending and strengthen the domestic 
information science industry.

In addition to its fine argument on the need to introduce free software in 
administration, the document lists ten directions and recommendations for 
future government action in that area. Although the directions don?t offer 
concrete requirements and quantities (for instance, the targeted share of open 
source software solutions), as well as deadline for implementation, but they 
do introduce clear imperatives that can, in the worst possible case, be used 
as strong advocacy basis.

===

how far this is gonna go is a riddle to us all, but I'm sure such a document 
makes lots of campanies very nervous :)

Cheers,

Auke

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Jul 19 19:09:39 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2006 19:09:39 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] My mail server is down for the moment...
In-Reply-To: <20060718175615.2B1BD478B@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200607200209.k6K29dTV022831@m5p.com>

>From: Ronald Chmara <ron at Opus1.COM>
> I know it's not much help now, but I have a *very* small list of things 
> I *never* do remotely:

Oh, you just lack courage!  :-)   ...insanity helps too.

> 1. kernel upgrades (if it bonks on the BIOS level, no remote daemon can 
> save you... the only fix would be a magic box that tunneled raw VGA 
> output, raw PS2/USB input, etc. over TCP/IP... is there such a beast?)

The thing is, being stuck at the LI prompt is actually more secure than a
problematic kernel. Your stuff is inaccessible to you, but it keeps the
intruders out as well.

With a distribution kernel though, this isn't all that hazardous. They
tend to ship working kernels, and the associated scripts tend to ensure
no steps are skipped (`pkgadd` a kernel patch on SunOS remotely, no
problem!). Also with GRUB understanding the filesystem and not needing to
be rerun, the danger has been greatly lessened. Still something to avoid
if you can, but a danger that can be minimized.

Installing a new custom kernel on a system 600 miles away which uses
LILO and Sun-style disk slices, definitely not for the faint of heart.
Finally got it to work for me though (the previous times I was a lot
closer, this time would of been a downtime of more than a week).

> 2. RAID juggling (if /boot is on a SCSI RAID 5, for example)
> 3. For that matter, anything SCSI. Requires waaaay too many goat 
> sacrifices when *at* the console to even consider doing remotely. (Or, 
> alternately, really good high end cables and terminators, which I 
> *never* seem to see IRL.)

You've got a method to install SCSI disks remotely? Impressive.

> 4. Any crypto library changes, or pam changes, if my sole admin access 
> is ssh. (Want to know how to make an sshd session work when the daemon 
> dies because libraries have changed? So do I.)

Problematic on SunOS where open() never returns EBUSY, elsewhere, pretty
easy. You just have to make sure to only kill the server sshd process,
and then test that you can get back in successfully (meaning you keep a
termninal with a root shell open while testing). Not danger free, but
something I do without many worries.

> 5. ifconfig changes (without a crond/atd backup script to restore 
> settings) on single NIC machines.
> 6. For that matter, ipchains/iptables/ipfw changes (without a crond/atd 
> backup script to restore settings) on even multi-NIC machines.

Yeah, know that one two. /Somewhat/ less dangerous than kernel upgrades
(less actually if you're using a package manager).

> Anybody else have warnings to add to the historical pool of "Ooops", so 
> future admin folks can spend less time pounding their heads mercilessly 
> into keyboards?

Not really, you've gotten the ones you have to worry most about. Though
of your list I think only 1, 5 and 6 are really major. 2 and 3 you need
to be at the console to juggle the hardware anyway.

> You're thinking of patents, which last 20 years.  Copyright, thanks to 
> the Sonny Bono CETA passed by Congress, last life + 75 years or a flat 
> 95 years for corporate-created works.  Any copyrights created by Tandy 
> 14 years ago will be in force until 2087.  And that's only if Congress 
> doesn't extend copyright terms again, which our Congresscritters have 
> been all too willing to do.  They get handsomely rewarded by the 
> entertainment and software lobbies for their cooperation.

The tradition is that 100 years is "forever". This is why things like the
Panama Canal treaty was for 99 years. Given that the Constitution
explicitly says "for a limited time", I hold some hope that next time the
Supreme Court will take action.

> I installed FC5 last night and then clicked the update link. It is still 
> downloading after around 12 hours (DSL line).
>
> What gives?

You probably hit a bad mirror.  Kill the process and restart yum. (Use "ps 
-auxw | grep yum" to find the process to kill.  It spawns a child process 
with a weird name.)

Yum does not have a way to tell if the mirror is not broken yet way too 
slow.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jul 19 20:44:51 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2006 20:44:51 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] I wonder if I can find an opinion here...

On Wed, 19 Jul 2006, Elliott Mitchell wrote:

>> From: Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
>> 1. GUI Administration vs. ASCII Config Files
>>
>> Apple's BSD underpinnings are mostly well-behaved. The hard part is 
>> getting the GUI to work and play well with ASCII config files. I 
>> like to keep configuration files in a Subversion repository and 
>> push into production via cfengine.
>>
>> But ... the minute I open the administrative GUI for any given 
>> daemon, the GUI will parse and re-write the config file, often 
>> removing comments or directives it doesn't understand (even if the 
>> underlying daemon *does* understand them).
>>
>> Then again, this isn't so much different from using GUI controls on 
>> Linux boxes. It's tough to mix and match administrative techniques.
>
> Oh yeah, I know this one. This is what makes me avoid RedHat. This 
> is much worse when your setup *requires* those options, and there is 
> no way to make the GUI tool add them. Particularly annoying when the 
> option has existed more or less forever.

For one-off machines or very small networks, GUI tools can save time. 
In larger networks with policy-driven configurations, they just get in 
the way.

Red Hat's tools are completely, 100% optional. In my experience, they 
only rewrite files when you specifically tell them to change 
something or other.

The Mac GUI tools are way more aggressive. They'll rewrite any time 
you open them, regardless of whether you actually change any settings. 
Ick.

Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>


From dave.houston at gmail.com  Wed Jul 19 20:48:46 2006
From: dave.houston at gmail.com (Dave Houston)
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2006 20:48:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Subversion question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191455080.11354@blackbox.fnordora.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191455080.11354@blackbox.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <1153367326.7095.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Untested: 

use strict;
use warnings;
use Getopt::Std;
my %opts;
getopt('flF', \%opts);
my $svn = "/path/to/svn";
for( $opts{f}+1..$opts{l} ) { 
    my ($prev, $this, $file) = ($_ - 1, $_, $opts{F});
    my $cmd = $svn . " -r $prev:$this $file";
    system $cmd;
}

Use it like foo.pl -f [first revision number] -l [last revision] -F
[file]

On Wed, 2006-07-19 at 14:58 -0700, alan wrote:

> changed from a specific date until now.

> What I want is to see what happened in each step along the way.  So if

> see the diff of that, then if there is a change from 4 to 5, I want to see 
> that change, etc.
> 
> I could write a script to diff each version, but that gets a bit tedious.
> 
> Suggestions?

From mike at mommabears.com  Wed Jul 19 21:50:30 2006
From: mike at mommabears.com (MJang)
Date: Wed, 19 Jul 2006 21:50:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] FC5 update question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191917320.13208@blackbox.fnordora.org>
References: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A970A8FCB7E@cityemail.bit.city>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191506010.30309@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<44BEB09B.9060201@foo-projects.org> <44BEB5EC.5030305@foo-projects.org>
	<7.0.1.0.0.20060719190638.043cebf0@earthlink.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191917320.13208@blackbox.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <1153371030.5238.7.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2006-07-19 at 19:20 -0700, alan wrote:
> On Wed, 19 Jul 2006, Jim Karlock wrote:
> 
> > I installed FC5 last night and then clicked the update link. It is still 
> > downloading after around 12 hours (DSL line).
> >
> > What gives?
> 
> You probably hit a bad mirror.  Kill the process and restart yum. (Use "ps 
> -auxw | grep yum" to find the process to kill.  It spawns a child process 
> with a weird name.)

By default, yum points to a random mirror among Fedora's worldwide
repositories. When I've checked, I've been connected to mirrors in NZ,
Germany, and Brazil. While they're working on a "fastestmirror" RPM for
FC6, the best approach for now is to revise the files in
the /etc/yum.repos.d directories to specific nearby mirrors. 

I recommend that you modify the baseurl directive to point to nearby
mirrors such as at kernel.org (hosted at OSU) and fedora.cat.pdx.edu.
Comment out the mirrorlist directives. Multiple baseurl directives in
each stanza are allowed.

Thanks,
Mike

From ron at Opus1.COM  Thu Jul 20 03:14:30 2006
From: ron at Opus1.COM (Ronald Chmara)

Subject: [PLUG] My mail server is down for the moment...
In-Reply-To: <200607200209.k6K29dTV022831@m5p.com>

On Jul 19, 2006, at 7:09 PM, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
>> From: Ronald Chmara <ron at Opus1.COM>
>> I know it's not much help now, but I have a *very* small list of 
>> things
>> I *never* do remotely:
> Oh, you just lack courage!  :-)   ...insanity helps too.

Well, occasionally I *will* do "cowboy" work, but those gigs come with 
hefty disclaimers and sign-offs. Or it's on my "own" old hardware 
(which, of course, I have already made nearly all the mistakes on, and 
thus know how to recover).

I guess *never* is more of a "never if I expect to keep a client for 
more than 6 months". Even when they've signed off to a policy which 
states "this may render the system permanently unusable", mgmt. folks 
want to know "how many minutes" until a system is back.

>> 1. kernel upgrades (if it bonks on the BIOS level, no remote daemon 
>> can
>> save you... the only fix would be a magic box that tunneled raw VGA
>> output, raw PS2/USB input, etc. over TCP/IP... is there such a beast?)
> The thing is, being stuck at the LI prompt is actually more secure 
> than a
> problematic kernel. Your stuff is inaccessible to you, but it keeps the
> intruders out as well.

Well, so does a melted motherboard. :-) Increases the time-to-recovery 
though.

> With a distribution kernel though, this isn't all that hazardous. They
> tend to ship working kernels, and the associated scripts tend to ensure
> no steps are skipped (`pkgadd` a kernel patch on SunOS remotely, no
> problem!). Also with GRUB understanding the filesystem and not needing 
> to
> be rerun, the danger has been greatly lessened. Still something to 
> avoid
> if you can, but a danger that can be minimized.

Yeah, if one can *get* to grub, and/or a functioning init level, it's 
possible to use a rollback/grub.conf change script to roll-back to a 
working state it, say, the rollback job isn't killed by a sysad getting 
a good login within 10 minutes after reboot/init/etc.

> Installing a new custom kernel on a system 600 miles away which uses
> LILO and Sun-style disk slices, definitely not for the faint of heart.

...custom binary RAID modules (gee, thanks, Dell!)...
...netboot+wireless drivers...

Basically, anything that has to do with lower-level access to a 
bootable kernel and enough being init'ed to login.

> Finally got it to work for me though (the previous times I was a lot
> closer, this time would of been a downtime of more than a week).
>> 2. RAID juggling (if /boot is on a SCSI RAID 5, for example)
>> 3. For that matter, anything SCSI. Requires waaaay too many goat
>> sacrifices when *at* the console to even consider doing remotely. (Or,
>> alternately, really good high end cables and terminators, which I
>> *never* seem to see IRL.)
> You've got a method to install SCSI disks remotely? Impressive.

Some colo's allow you to ship hardware to be installed with minimal 
instructions like "stick this in the RAID module bay with the failure 
light". I'd advise against doing it, or expect to burn long distance 
minutes pretty heavily.

>> 4. Any crypto library changes, or pam changes, if my sole admin access
>> is ssh. (Want to know how to make an sshd session work when the daemon
>> dies because libraries have changed? So do I.)
> Problematic on SunOS where open() never returns EBUSY, elsewhere, 
> pretty
> easy. You just have to make sure to only kill the server sshd process,
> and then test that you can get back in successfully (meaning you keep a
> termninal with a root shell open while testing). Not danger free, but
> something I do without many worries.

I've nuked this lots of times on linux with hand re-compiles (for speed 
reasons) of various crypto-libs over the years (make install step).... 
I just got into the habit of making a "safe, outside of program space, 
login" (usually telnet from a machine inside the perimeter). Maybe this 
rule is just because of working with some cruftier boxen, or I'm 
missing something simple. I dunno.

>> 5. ifconfig changes (without a crond/atd backup script to restore
>> settings) on single NIC machines.
>> 6. For that matter, ipchains/iptables/ipfw changes (without a 
>> crond/atd
>> backup script to restore settings) on even multi-NIC machines.
> Yeah, know that one two. /Somewhat/ less dangerous than kernel upgrades
> (less actually if you're using a package manager).
>> Anybody else have warnings to add to the historical pool of "Ooops", 
>> so
>> future admin folks can spend less time pounding their heads 
>> mercilessly
>> into keyboards?
> Not really, you've gotten the ones you have to worry most about. Though
> of your list I think only 1, 5 and 6 are really major. 2 and 3 you need
> to be at the console to juggle the hardware anyway.

Well, 2 and 3 are really things that should be possible to do mostly 
remotely (aside from physical moving of disks), *provided* that the 
booting system components, and the raid system components, being 
juggled, are separate.

Example: say a big fileserver with lots of images. 'images' is a RAID 
mount at /home/Images. Server can boot with, or without, the RAID or 
RAID modules. If software RAID, this can be juggled remotely. If 
hardware/BIOS raid... it's trickier.

Hm... Oh wait. I don't have anything in the list yet about MBR-related 
proggies... they belong somewhere in there, no? Upgrades that 
(not-so-nicely) "repair" or "refresh" or "replace" a MBR?

-Bop

> > doesn't extend copyright terms again, which our Congresscritters have 
> > been all too willing to do.  They get handsomely rewarded by the 
> > entertainment and software lobbies for their cooperation.
> 
> The tradition is that 100 years is "forever". This is why things like the
> Panama Canal treaty was for 99 years. Given that the Constitution
> explicitly says "for a limited time", I hold some hope that next time the
> Supreme Court will take action.

Well, can someone explain how AMD, Intel, etc. produce processors 
that support the same binaries without violating copyrights?  Does 
each competing company reinvent the  wheel?  Imagine where the 
electronics industry would be today if noone, save one company, 
could produce transistors without paying a huge royalty?

Practically speaking, you probably only need a copyright for 10 years 
or less to profit from your work.  Even where copyright means you have
to pay to use someone else's idea seperately from them, that's
reasonable if the price isn't too high.  It seems the idea behind
copyrights is that a business, at least temporarily, needs a monopoly
to offset the cost of it's development.  Trouble is, that company
can control that idea even if that means leaving people behind who
want to see it taken further.

The GPL was created to solve a problem, the inability to share software
freely and efficiently.  Is there an analogue to it for electronic 
hardware?  Are the days when Commodores came with blue prints behind
us?

-------------------------------------------------

> I recommend that you modify the baseurl directive to point to nearby

> Comment out the mirrorlist directives. Multiple baseurl directives in

I used to use fedora.cat.pdx.edu as my rsync source, but I had
occasional failures when rsyncd hadn't been enabled at boot time; at one
point I found I hadn't gotten an update in a week or more, so I gave up
and switched to mirrors.kernel.org and haven't really had any problems
since.

If you can find (or get some to make for you) a pre-setup virtual
machine, you can use vmware player for free.  It runs all machines
created by vmware workstation or others, it just can't create its own.

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Jul 20 10:45:34 2006
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 2006 10:45:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Encrypted data pass-phrase
Message-ID: <44BFC13E.4060105@acm.org>

If that isn't vague enough I'll try to confuse it some more with details.

I'm working on a system that needs to run charges against customers 
credit cards periodically or sporadically.  This will typically be more 
than one card at a time at a time and could happen anywhere from once a 
year to twice a day.

The CC numbers are encrypted before being stored.

We'd prefer to not have someone sitting at the console :-) entering the 
pass-phrase for each run.

We've come up with several ideas how to make this fairly secure and 
hands-off but I have the impression several on the list have done 
something similar and might have other ( better ) ideas.


TIA,
Rod

On Wed, 19 Jul 2006, plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:

> I'm trying to work with an evaluation copy of Redhat 8 and need to strip it
> down as much as possible.

WHY????

Redhat 8 is broken.  Redhat 9 fixed most of the brokeness of that version, 
but not all of it.  If you have to use something that old, I suggest using 
either Redhat 7.3 or Redhat 9.

Just don't put it out unprotected on the net.

As for package management, there are not any real useful tools for Redhat 
8/9.  You might be able to build Yum for it.  All the older tools are a 
headache and a half.

Be careful with lubricants, and follow the manufactures recommendations 
when possible. Oil mixed with dust bunnies can make the problem worse. 
When in doubt, I use a graphite lubricant. On a similar note, WD-40 is 
not intended to be a lubricant, but rather a solvent.

When I worked for DEC, a vacuum/blower was standard equipment for 
preventive maintenance.

On Thu, 20 Jul 2006, Christian Bewley wrote:

> I have RH9 that I could kick to you as well.... I have both single 
> disc and 3 disc installation sets. Maybe even meet up this 
> afternoon?

If you really need RH 9 or RH 7.3, I'd suggest taking a serious look 
at CentOS 2 and 3, which are Free rebuilds of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 
2.1 and 3. RHEL 2.1 is quite like RH 7, RHEL 3 like RH 9. The 
end-of-life promises on these products are quite specific:

  RHEL 4 (see CentOS 4):   Feb 29, 2012
  RHEL 3 (see CentOS 3):   Oct 31, 2010
  RHEL 2.1 (see CentOS 2): May 31, 2009

  Source: http://www.redhat.com/security/updates/errata/

The Fedora Legacy project has, to my mind, been quite spotty in 
maintaining updates (of course, it's not like I've pitched in to help, 
so I'm not really casting blame...), while RHEL/CentOS updates are 
typically quite timely.

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Jul 20 14:29:01 2006

On Thu, 20 Jul 2006, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Anyone know the general status of udev these days? Do all the major
> distributions use it now, or are there still some devfs holdouts? Somewheres
> I read that from kernel 2.6.13 on, you get only udev. But anymore I'm a
> little paranoid about the many ways individual distributions can bork I mean
> customize their offerings...

Devfs is dead, dead, dead.  It has not seen an update in over a year.  The 
only distro that used it to any extent was Mandrake and it was buggy as 
hell.  The kernel maintainers are planning on removing it from the kernel 
as soon as they can, if not sooner.  (Greg KH has been trying to kill it 
for a while now.)

I am not certain if udev or sysfs is the "one true way" at this point.
