From ogmoid at gmail.com  Thu Jul 20 20:06:35 2006
From: ogmoid at gmail.com (Nathaniel Nuss)
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 2006 20:06:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Subversion question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191455080.11354@blackbox.fnordora.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607191455080.11354@blackbox.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <20060721030635.GG16194@tob.losaca.adelphia.net>

On Wed, Jul 19, 2006 at 02:58:28PM -0700, alan wrote:
> I have a piece of code in a subversion repository.  I want to see what 
> changed from a specific date until now.
> 
> But...
> 
> What I want is to see what happened in each step along the way.  So if 
> there was a change to the file from revision 3 to revision 4, I want to 
> see the diff of that, then if there is a change from 4 to 5, I want to see 
> that change, etc.

Are you perhaps working in a repository where there might be large gaps
in the sequence (from commits happening in areas you aren't interested
in maybe) ?

> I could write a script to diff each version, but that gets a bit tedious.

svn log -r $BEGIN:$END --quiet $REPO_OR_PATH   | \  
sed -e '/^-\+$/d' -e 's/^r\([0-9]\+\).\+$/\1/' | \ 
{ while read rev; do svn diff -r "$rev" $REPO_OR_PATH > "r${rev}.diff"; done }

I expect that to get the relevant revision numbers (stripping off cruft)
then one-by-one create a number of files between r$BEGIN.diff and r$END.diff .

> Suggestions?

Might:
svnadmin dump (with appropriate revision range, delta and incremental usage)
followed by a 
svndumpfilter (include/exclude to get what you want)
... be the droids you're looking for?

The output would be an svn dumpfile containing the changes you are
interested in - which is fairly readable and brings in some changes a
usual svn diff won't/can't. You could also play-it-back into a
temporary repository if that was a good way to work with it.

! This does have the distinct drawback of being, probably, the most resource intensive !

-- 
Nate Nuss


From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Thu Jul 20 20:59:02 2006
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Thu, 20 Jul 2006 21:59:02 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs Timestamp Entries In Files
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607201945280.16618@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607201945280.16618@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607202111440.20754@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>

Maybe add a function to Semantic Highlight Edits Mode Hook or Vc Before
Checkin Hook?  Or write a save function of your own, and bind it to a
keychord of your choice.  That's how to get the timestamp function to
run at the right time.

To actually write a timestamp into a file, I scraped this up online.
Function foo is the one you call with M-x foo while in the buffer you
want to timestamp and save.  The other 3 functions just give you a
choice of date formats.

I didn't bother placing the timestamp with much elegance because I don't
know where you need it exactly.  Elisp buffer functions are easy enough
to find docs for and use.

(defun foo ()
   (interactive)
   (goto-char (point-min))
   (insert (insert-date-iso))
   (save-buffer))

(defun insert-date-iso ()
   "Inserts the current local date and time (to the minute) into the current buffer
before Point. The data are formatted per ISO 8601 specification. This is useful for
prefixing entries in a log book."
   (interactive)
   (setq now (decode-time)
         final-string (format "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d+%d"
                              (nth 5 now)          ; yyyy
                              (nth 4 now)          ; mm
                              (nth 3 now)          ; dd
                              (nth 2 now)          ; HH
                              (nth 1 now)          ; MM
                              (/ (nth 8 now) 36))) ; UTCO
   (insert final-string))

(defun insert-date-stamp ()
   "Inserts the current local date into the current buffer before Point. The data are
formatted per ISO 8601 short specification and prefixed with my initials 'MJL'. This
is useful for inserting mod comments into code files."
   (interactive)
   (setq now (decode-time)
         final-string (format "MJL%04d%02d%02d - "
                              (nth 5 now)          ; yyyy
                              (nth 4 now)          ; mm
                              (nth 3 now)))        ; dd
   (insert final-string))

(defun insert-date-dow ()
   "Inserts the current local date and the day of the week into the current buffer
before Point. The date data are formatted per ISO 8601 specification. The DOW is
expanded to the full name. This is useful for prefixing day entries in a log book."
   (interactive)
   (setq DOWlist '(Sunday Monday Tuesday Wednesday Thursday Friday Saturday))
   (setq now (decode-time)
         final-string (format "%04d-%02d-%02d %s"
                              (nth 5 now)                 ; yyyy
                              (nth 4 now)                 ; mm
                              (nth 3 now)                 ; dd
                              (nth (nth 6 now) DOWlist))) ; day
   (insert final-string))


Carlos Konstanski

> > distributions use it now, or are there still some devfs holdouts? Somewheres
> > I read that from kernel 2.6.13 on, you get only udev. But anymore I'm a
> > little paranoid about the many ways individual distributions can bork I mean
> > customize their offerings...
>
> Devfs is dead, dead, dead.  It has not seen an update in over a year.  The
> only distro that used it to any extent was Mandrake and it was buggy as
> hell.  The kernel maintainers are planning on removing it from the kernel
> as soon as they can, if not sooner.  (Greg KH has been trying to kill it
> for a while now.)

And was finally successful *very* recently.

http://www.kroah.com/log/2006/06/29/#2006_06_29

> I am not certain if udev or sysfs is the "one true way" at this point.

They are complimentary.  udev is userspace, so it uses sysfs to get
information about the system state when it is signaled by
/sbin/hotplug.

I cheated for my date function, and just used a shell command:

(defun enter-date nil
  "Enter today's date at point."
  (interactive)
  (shell-command "date '+%B %d, %Y'" 1))

Ali

On 7/20/06, Carlos Konstanski <ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com> wrote:
> Maybe add a function to Semantic Highlight Edits Mode Hook or Vc Before
> Checkin Hook?  Or write a save function of your own, and bind it to a
> keychord of your choice.  That's how to get the timestamp function to
> run at the right time.
>
> To actually write a timestamp into a file, I scraped this up online.
> Function foo is the one you call with M-x foo while in the buffer you
> want to timestamp and save.  The other 3 functions just give you a
> choice of date formats.
>
> I didn't bother placing the timestamp with much elegance because I don't
> know where you need it exactly.  Elisp buffer functions are easy enough
> to find docs for and use.
>
> (defun foo ()
>    (interactive)
>    (goto-char (point-min))
>    (insert (insert-date-iso))
>    (save-buffer))
>
> (defun insert-date-iso ()
>    "Inserts the current local date and time (to the minute) into the current buffer
> before Point. The data are formatted per ISO 8601 specification. This is useful for
> prefixing entries in a log book."
>    (interactive)
>    (setq now (decode-time)
>          final-string (format "%04d-%02d-%02dT%02d:%02d+%d"
>                               (nth 5 now)          ; yyyy
>                               (nth 4 now)          ; mm
>                               (nth 3 now)          ; dd
>                               (nth 2 now)          ; HH
>                               (nth 1 now)          ; MM
>                               (/ (nth 8 now) 36))) ; UTCO
>    (insert final-string))
>
> (defun insert-date-stamp ()
>    "Inserts the current local date into the current buffer before Point. The data are
> formatted per ISO 8601 short specification and prefixed with my initials 'MJL'. This
> is useful for inserting mod comments into code files."
>    (interactive)
>    (setq now (decode-time)
>          final-string (format "MJL%04d%02d%02d - "
>                               (nth 5 now)          ; yyyy
>                               (nth 4 now)          ; mm
>                               (nth 3 now)))        ; dd
>    (insert final-string))
>
> (defun insert-date-dow ()
>    "Inserts the current local date and the day of the week into the current buffer
> before Point. The date data are formatted per ISO 8601 specification. The DOW is
> expanded to the full name. This is useful for prefixing day entries in a log book."
>    (interactive)
>    (setq DOWlist '(Sunday Monday Tuesday Wednesday Thursday Friday Saturday))
>    (setq now (decode-time)
>          final-string (format "%04d-%02d-%02d %s"
>                               (nth 5 now)                 ; yyyy
>                               (nth 4 now)                 ; mm
>                               (nth 3 now)                 ; dd
>                               (nth (nth 6 now) DOWlist))) ; day
>    (insert final-string))
>
>
> Carlos Konstanski

Think about it.  ~/.login
/usr/sbin/chroot $HOME

with symlink in home directory:

ls -l $HOME

drwxr-x--- <user> users .
crwxr-xr-x  root  root  ..
drwxrwxrwx  root  root  home

cd home
ls -l
lrwxrwxrwx  root  root  ../.. <user>


You would need to have executables within your jail.  Libraries also.
Much work.  If you system is one partition, hard links might work.  Mine
isn't so cannot run chroot.
kens at atlas ~]$ sudo !!
sudo /usr/sbin/chroot $HOME
Password:
/usr/sbin/chroot: cannot run command `/bin/bash': No such file or
directory
[kens at atlas ~]$ pwd
/home/kens
[kens at atlas ~]$ pwd
/home/kens
[kens at atlas ~]$ df -h
Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda2              32G   20G   11G  64% /
/dev/sda1              99M   13M   81M  14% /boot
/dev/shm              1.5G     0  1.5G   0% /dev/shm
/dev/sdb1              34G   15G   18G  45% /home
[kens at atlas ~]$

Ken
CAD 2 CAM




From sofar at foo-projects.org  Fri Jul 21 07:37:45 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 2006 07:37:45 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] setting up SSH to chr[o]ot to user homeDir
In-Reply-To: <44C05B6C.2020500@emediatedesigns.com>
References: <44C05B6C.2020500@emediatedesigns.com>
Message-ID: <44C0E6B9.6070000@foo-projects.org>

Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> Been looking about the wonderful web and reading about how I could 
> achieve this but all that I've found makes it sound like I need to setup 
> yet another customer product of sorts.  So...
> 
> Is there a way that I can configure SSHD to allow clients to login but 
> be chrooted to their home directory?
> FTP does this well and I would like to have it do the same for SSHD.  
> I'm actually surprised this isn't a configuration option on OpenSSH as 
> it would make sense that you would want to allow certain shell access 
> but not allow all people to go about browsing your entire server.
> So, is this possible?  Do I need some sort of custom SSH or is there 
> another program I can use to give secure Shell access?

TINST

as Kenneth already explained this is very much a nightmare to setup, and FTP 
can do it since the user only needs 1 exectuable (ftpd) running on the server 
after login, so that executable itself can chroot at startup.

If you really want to permit users to login but not see something outside of 
their homedirectories, then you should investigate more secure ways (chroots 
can be busted, yes even with grsecurity) such as UML or providing a fully 
chrooted install with sshd running already in it.

If you're only looking into offering limited functionality (e.g. sftp-server) 
you might also want to see if you can get around it by just allowing the user 
to run only one type of connection that way.

Cheers,

Auke

Many of you have been interested in ArchGenXML for some time, some may 
already have been experimenting with it, others may have not even heard 
of this great RAD tool for Plone. Some of you may have seen a demo of it 
first hand at some event, read something about it online, or seen one of 
a few pod-casts that show off this amazing technology as the 
demonstrator cranks out a new Plone product almost faster than you can 
follow.

To put it simply, ArchGenXML allows you to create fully functional, 
ready to install, Plone products from a drawing. In this apparent magic 
act, the drawing is a UML diagram and the resulting product is based on 
Archetypes.

This technology is not actually magical, does allow a developer to 
quickly visualize an idea and move it into a working product very 
quickly. This tool is the product of the hard work and dedication of 
many key developers in the Plone community. Every user has a different 
perspective on how it fits into their tool-set, and how deep down the 
rabbit hole they tend to plunge, but all will agree that it is a key 
feather in the Plone development communities hat.

We will be spending most of three days delving into all aspects of this 
tool. Every student will leave with both first hand knowledge of the 
capabilities of this tool, and personal experience in it's use. We will 
also explore other related tools including the future replacement of 
ArchGenXML, Genesis.

We will start with a foundation that will allow you to best capitalize 
on the benefits ArchGenXML has to offer, starting with a quick reminder 
of what it means to be a product in Plone, then an overview of 
Archetypes, and then into an introduction to UML. This foundation will 
give us a solid base from which to build our understanding of ArchGenXML.

dictates as well as other Plone trainings. See our website for details.

What about setting the users shell to rbash or bash -r.

>From the bash man page:
RESTRICTED SHELL
       If bash is started with the name rbash, or the -r option is supplied at
       invocation,  the  shell becomes restricted.  A restricted shell is used
       to set up an environment more controlled than the standard  shell.   It
       behaves  identically  to bash with the exception that the following are
       disallowed or not performed:

             changing directories with cd
             setting or unsetting the values of SHELL, PATH, ENV, or BASH_ENV
             specifying command names containing /
             specifying  a  file  name containing a / as an argument to the .
                builtin command
             Specifying a filename containing a slash as an argument  to  the
                -p option to the hash builtin command
             importing  function  definitions  from  the shell environment at
                startup
             parsing the value of SHELLOPTS from  the  shell  environment  at
                startup
             redirecting  output using the >, >|, <>, >&, &>, and >> redirec-
                tion operators
             using the exec builtin command to replace the shell with another
                command
             adding  or  deleting builtin commands with the -f and -d options
                to the enable builtin command
             Using the  enable  builtin  command  to  enable  disabled  shell
                builtins
             specifying the -p option to the command builtin command
             turning off restricted mode with set +r or set +o restricted.

From tcslighter at gmail.com  Fri Jul 21 10:45:32 2006
From: tcslighter at gmail.com (Tim Slighter)
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 2006 10:45:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] setting up SSH to chrrot to user homeDir
In-Reply-To: <ca5165530607211009v6ddd3422kff806ee764704742@mail.gmail.com>
References: <44C05B6C.2020500@emediatedesigns.com>
	<ca5165530607211009v6ddd3422kff806ee764704742@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <65244f100607211045q33ee7729j683168a69649fe9f@mail.gmail.com>

The rbash idea is a good one but there are still many more steps to take to
make sure the user stays within that shell and within the confines of their
home directory.  You have to create a directory somewhere like /usr/progs
and put the binaries and only the binaries that you want the user to have
access to and then declare that directory and the users only path in their
.bash_profile or .bashrc or both.  Better off if any programs with potential
shell escapes like pine, vi, emacs etc, are all replaced with a restricted
version of the binary such as rvi or rvim, etc.  You will also need to
declare restrictive aliases for each user to prevent them access to any
other shells so declare an alias for ksh to /bin/rbash and csh ->
/bin/rbash, so what you are doing here is making sure that any shell they
attempt to get to will always put them back into and keep them in rbash.
 Make sure also that you prevent them from using the unalias command by
declaring that to /bin/rbash as well and then you must prevent the user from
modifying the file so do a chattr +i on the .bashrc or .bash_profile files
in their home directories.  I did manage to do this but it was a pain and
quite a bit of work and a lot of trial and error.  Feel free to ask
questions if you need help with this.

On 7/21/06, Larry Brigman <larry.brigman at gmail.com> wrote:
>
> On 7/20/06, Josh Orchard <josh at emediatedesigns.com> wrote:
> > Hello all,
> >
> > Been looking about the wonderful web and reading about how I could
> > achieve this but all that I've found makes it sound like I need to setup
> > yet another customer product of sorts.  So...
> >
> > Is there a way that I can configure SSHD to allow clients to login but
> > be chrooted to their home directory?
> >
> > FTP does this well and I would like to have it do the same for SSHD.
> > I'm actually surprised this isn't a configuration option on OpenSSH as
> > it would make sense that you would want to allow certain shell access
> > but not allow all people to go about browsing your entire server.
> >
> > So, is this possible?  Do I need some sort of custom SSH or is there
> > another program I can use to give secure Shell access?
> >
>
> What about setting the users shell to rbash or bash -r.
>
> >From the bash man page:
> RESTRICTED SHELL
>        If bash is started with the name rbash, or the -r option is
> supplied at
>        invocation,  the  shell becomes restricted.  A restricted shell is
> used
>        to set up an environment more controlled than the
> standard  shell.   It
>        behaves  identically  to bash with the exception that the following
> are
>        disallowed or not performed:
>
>              changing directories with cd
>              setting or unsetting the values of SHELL, PATH, ENV, or
> BASH_ENV
>              specifying command names containing /
>              specifying  a  file  name containing a / as an argument to
> the .
>                 builtin command
>              Specifying a filename containing a slash as an
> argument  to  the
>                 -p option to the hash builtin command
>              importing  function  definitions  from  the shell environment
> at
>                 startup
>              parsing the value of SHELLOPTS
> from  the  shell  environment  at
>                 startup
>              redirecting  output using the >, >|, <>, >&, &>, and >>
> redirec-
>                 tion operators
>              using the exec builtin command to replace the shell with
> another
>                 command
>              adding  or  deleting builtin commands with the -f and -d
> options
>                 to the enable builtin command
>              Using
> the  enable  builtin  command  to  enable  disabled  shell
>                 builtins
>              specifying the -p option to the command builtin command
>              turning off restricted mode with set +r or set +o restricted.

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From xrdawson at gmail.com  Fri Jul 21 11:02:30 2006
From: xrdawson at gmail.com (Chris Dawson)
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 2006 11:02:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] setting up SSH to chrrot to user homeDir
In-Reply-To: <65244f100607211045q33ee7729j683168a69649fe9f@mail.gmail.com>
References: <44C05B6C.2020500@emediatedesigns.com>
	<ca5165530607211009v6ddd3422kff806ee764704742@mail.gmail.com>
	<65244f100607211045q33ee7729j683168a69649fe9f@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <659b9ea30607211102u6a5a0e4bp7ebd0cb558a693d9@mail.gmail.com>

This worked for me using rbash:

Create an account where login shell is rbash.  Create a .bashrc like
this in the user's home directory:

PATH=/opt/wiab/binary_data/upload/bin
PS1='Master Upload #

I symlinked only the applications I wanted into
/opt/wiab/binary_data/upload/bin.  You can only run those applications
when you are logged in.

Chris

We're just getting an "interesting" set of systems tied together.  One 
provides an nfs share for three others.

While fiddling around with the iptables settings on one of the nfs 
clients ( so I can access it from home this week-end I ) I did a service 
sshd restart.  Just few seconds later one of our testers reported an 
error related to a part of the application that accessed the share.

Sure enough a quick 'df' on the client hung at the nfs portion ... 
really hung and a check of the server said the mount was busy.  Finally 
I restarted  'nfs' and the nfs mount ... mounted.

The iptables setup ( and nfs configuration ) is pretty simple and based 
on some research that lead me to a Redhat page.

So is anyone else doing nfs and running iptables?  Does this feel like 
an iptables issue?


TIA,

> PATH=/opt/wiab/binary_data/upload/bin
> PS1='Master Upload #
>
> I symlinked only the applications I wanted into
> /opt/wiab/binary_data/upload/bin.  You can only run those applications
> when you are logged in.
>
> Chris
>

From eli.stair at gmail.com  Fri Jul 21 16:06:29 2006
From: eli.stair at gmail.com (Eli Stair)
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 2006 16:06:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] iptables and nfs
In-Reply-To: <44C1535D.4080804@acm.org>
References: <44C1535D.4080804@acm.org>
Message-ID: <f4468cae0607211606y2cb567ebw8e4e7dd867c04a7a@mail.gmail.com>

Post your iptables script, and the output of an 'iptables --list'.

Also, if you can recreate and test the ussue, it'd be good to watch
some ethereal captures during it to see if you're getting RST's, ICMP
unreachable, invalid or otherwise bogus traffic patterns on port
connects.

One thing that came to mind, a lot of older distros have shown me
issues with the RPC advertised ports not matching up to the port the
daemon is running on (i.e. rpcinfo -p differs from the port
mountd/statd, etc are listening on).  You didnt' mention specifics, so
it's kinda hard to do anything but speculate :)


/eli

The man page says:

"the following are disallowed or not performed:

       ?      changing directories with cd
,,,,"

So, no, you cannot change directories.

Read the man page.  The first page is super simple and tells you
everthing you need to know.

Chris

From tcslighter at gmail.com  Fri Jul 21 17:27:27 2006
From: tcslighter at gmail.com (Tim Slighter)
Date: Fri, 21 Jul 2006 17:27:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] setting up SSH to chrrot to user homeDir
In-Reply-To: <44C160A0.2020405@emediatedesigns.com>
References: <44C05B6C.2020500@emediatedesigns.com>
	<ca5165530607211009v6ddd3422kff806ee764704742@mail.gmail.com>
	<65244f100607211045q33ee7729j683168a69649fe9f@mail.gmail.com>
	<44C160A0.2020405@emediatedesigns.com>
Message-ID: <65244f100607211727g58b89b87t41e6cb53c440484a@mail.gmail.com>

pretty easy, just use the alias command in their .bashrc file like this

alias sh='/bin/rbash'
alias ksh='/bin/rbash'
alias csh='/bin/rbash'
alias bash='/bin/rbash'
alias tcsh='/bin/rbash'
alias unalias='/bin/rbash'

And add to that any other shells that might possibly be on the system such
as ash or zsh etc...then make both .bashrc and .bash_profile immutable using
chattr +i /home/user1/.bashrc and chattr +i /home/user1/.bash_profile.  Make
you test everything out first that you have implemented before you do the
chattr or you have to chattr -i all of them, make your changes and then back
to immutable.  The way I did it is by allowing them access to very few
binaries such as vi, ls, cat, grep and mail (you can definitely add others)
and I copied all of these files into a new directory /usr/progs and then put
that directory as the only path in their .bashrc and .bash_profile files.
 Be careful about dropping vi in their as that will allow them an escape
shell so you might have to download vim, but if you already have it then do
the same thing as with bash and copy the vim binary to rvim and then copy
that to the /usr/progs directory.  Also check the mail utility if you are
going to use it to make there is no escape shell or you will also have to
address that issue.  the less access you give them to programs, the less
likely they are to break out of a shell.  You may also want to prevent them
from accessing the chsh utility and might have to alias that to '/bin/rbash'
as well.  Then just test it out locally using your extra screen consoles
(alt - F2 - alt - F3 etc..) and log in as that user and try anything and
everything possible to break out of your shell and to also break out of your
working directory.  Eventually you will get it and then you can chattr +i
those two files.

> >> BASH_ENV

> >> argument  to  the

> >> environment
> >> at

> >>                 tion operators

Message-ID: <65244f100607211730j6c4e117yb999d0051acf5b3@mail.gmail.com>

There is one thing i thought of that can bite you in the behind and that is
the ssh keys.  when you generate the user's ssh keys (ssh-keygen -t dsa),
make sure that the keys go directly into the users home directory and not
into ~/.ssh or the user will never be able to successfully ssh to the
system.  Because remember that rbash does not allow cd into any
directory except the working directory.


On 7/21/06, Tim Slighter <tcslighter at gmail.com> wrote:
>
> pretty easy, just use the alias command in their .bashrc file like this
>
> alias sh='/bin/rbash'
> alias ksh='/bin/rbash'
> alias csh='/bin/rbash'
> alias bash='/bin/rbash'
> alias tcsh='/bin/rbash'
> alias unalias='/bin/rbash'
>
> And add to that any other shells that might possibly be on the system such
> as ash or zsh etc...then make both .bashrc and .bash_profile immutable using
> chattr +i /home/user1/.bashrc and chattr +i /home/user1/.bash_profile.  Make
> you test everything out first that you have implemented before you do the
> chattr or you have to chattr -i all of them, make your changes and then back
> to immutable.  The way I did it is by allowing them access to very few
> binaries such as vi, ls, cat, grep and mail (you can definitely add others)
> and I copied all of these files into a new directory /usr/progs and then put
> that directory as the only path in their .bashrc and .bash_profile files.
>  Be careful about dropping vi in their as that will allow them an escape
> shell so you might have to download vim, but if you already have it then do
> the same thing as with bash and copy the vim binary to rvim and then copy
> that to the /usr/progs directory.  Also check the mail utility if you are
> going to use it to make there is no escape shell or you will also have to
> address that issue.  the less access you give them to programs, the less
> likely they are to break out of a shell.  You may also want to prevent them
> from accessing the chsh utility and might have to alias that to '/bin/rbash'
> as well.  Then just test it out locally using your extra screen consoles
> (alt - F2 - alt - F3 etc..) and log in as that user and try anything and
> everything possible to break out of your shell and to also break out of your
> working directory.  Eventually you will get it and then you can chattr +i
> those two files.
>
>

Please make the following corrections to the aliases as the alias command
does not accept "/".

alias sh='rbash'
alias csh='rbash'
alias ksh='rbash'
alias tcsh='rbash'
alias unalias='rbash'
alias chsh='rbash'


etc.....

If you want to lock out shell access in mail, just drop in a .mailrc file in
their home directory with "unset shell" in it and chattr +i the file and you
should be all set.  I just did it on my system with a new user and they
cannot escape the shell or working directory.

Sort of reminds me of working for a government contractor at a
governnment facility.  The removed the rm function so we could not
delete files.  We figured out we could delete files anyway with the move
command.  cp /dev/zero to ~/zero.  cp ~/zero file-to-delete.

From eterry at openboxbuilder.com  Fri Jul 21 22:37:21 2006
From: eterry at openboxbuilder.com (Edward Terry)
Date: Sat, 22 Jul 2006 01:37:21 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Suse 10.1 License question
In-Reply-To: <20060721171601.30D114732@ulke.nakedape.cc>
References: <20060721171601.30D114732@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <44C1B991.9060509@openboxbuilder.com>

> Just because I have a bad habit of reading these things ---  Does any
> one know if the following is new in Suse 10.1 or not.  
> 
> The part I am interested in is the "You may make and distribute
> unlimited copies of the Software outside Your organization provided
> that: 1) You receive no consideration; and, 2) you do not bundle or
> combine the Software with another offering".  
> 
> Being a consultant that enjoys eating and ....  I would rather not see this.

I don't know if the wording has changed, but Novell's policies have not. 
  I asked SUSE about this before their acquisition.  Later, after 
openSUSE was announced, I asked them if it had changed.  SUSE, including 
openSUSE, cannot be resold (whether standalone, as part of a software 
bundle, or preloaded on a system) without paying per copy.  Before the 
acquisition, SUSE required purchase of the actual boxed product for 
resale (at least for small resellers).  Now, Novell will allow resellers 
to burn their own media, but they must still pay on a per-copy basis.

Mandriva has similar requirements.  Fedora can be sold free of charge.

Edward

command so they can at least change directories inside a homeDir? 

Thanks for all the help.

Josh


Tim Slighter wrote:
> Please make the following corrections to the aliases as the alias 
> command does not accept "/".
>
> alias sh='rbash'
> alias csh='rbash'
> alias ksh='rbash'
> alias tcsh='rbash'
> alias unalias='rbash'
> alias chsh='rbash'
>
>
> etc.....
>
> If you want to lock out shell access in mail, just drop in a .mailrc 
> file in their home directory with "unset shell" in it and chattr +i 
> the file and you should be all set.  I just did it on my system with a 
> new user and they cannot escape the shell or working directory.
>
> On 7/21/06, *Tim Slighter* <tcslighter at gmail.com 
> <mailto:tcslighter at gmail.com>> wrote:
>
>     There is one thing i thought of that can bite you in the behind
>     and that is the ssh keys.  when you generate the user's ssh keys
>     (ssh-keygen -t dsa), make sure that the keys go directly into the
>     users home directory and not into ~/.ssh or the user will never be
>     able to successfully ssh to the
>     system.  Because remember that rbash does not allow cd into any directory except the working directory.
>
>
>     On 7/21/06, *Tim Slighter* < tcslighter at gmail.com
>     <mailto:tcslighter at gmail.com>> wrote:
>
>         pretty easy, just use the alias command in their .bashrc file
>         like this
>
>         alias sh='/bin/rbash'
>         alias ksh='/bin/rbash'
>         alias csh='/bin/rbash'
>         alias bash='/bin/rbash'
>         alias tcsh='/bin/rbash'
>         alias unalias='/bin/rbash'
>
>         And add to that any other shells that might possibly be on the
>         system such as ash or zsh etc...then make both .bashrc and
>         .bash_profile immutable using chattr +i /home/user1/.bashrc
>         and chattr +i /home/user1/.bash_profile.  Make you test
>         everything out first that you have implemented before you do
>         the chattr or you have to chattr -i all of them, make your
>         changes and then back to immutable.  The way I did it is by
>         allowing them access to very few binaries such as vi, ls, cat,
>         grep and mail (you can definitely add others) and I copied all
>         of these files into a new directory /usr/progs and then put
>         that directory as the only path in their .bashrc and
>         .bash_profile files.  Be careful about dropping vi in their as
>         that will allow them an escape shell so you might have to
>         download vim, but if you already have it then do the same
>         thing as with bash and copy the vim binary to rvim and then
>         copy that to the /usr/progs directory.  Also check the mail
>         utility if you are going to use it to make there is no escape
>         shell or you will also have to address that issue.  the less
>         access you give them to programs, the less likely they are to
>         break out of a shell.  You may also want to prevent them from
>         accessing the chsh utility and might have to alias that to
>         '/bin/rbash' as well.  Then just test it out locally using
>         your extra screen consoles (alt - F2 - alt - F3 etc..) and log
>         in as that user and try anything and everything possible to
>         break out of your shell and to also break out of your working
>         directory.  Eventually you will get it and then you can chattr
>         +i those two files.
>
>

Yes I saw this.  I have been unable to sleep and thus was thinking of 
ways to solve this.  I think I have found a way. 

Since I have restricted the path to one bin directory and also limited 
the shell access with the aliases and using rbash,  why not write a 
script that would take the first argument and check against a variable 
called chrootDir and see if the argument of the command matched the 
chrootDir Variable.  You'd have to take the argument and turn it into an 
absolute path to check but would something like this work?  Does someone 
have a suggestion on how I could do this in bash?  I suppose it could be 
a perl script or something too. 

Here is what I'm thinking:

set a variable:  chrootDir=/home/user  in the .bashrc file, which the 
user can't change.

Put a script in the rbashBin directory of  'rcd' 

The user executes:
rcd mydir

The script then takes the absolute path of the first argument which 
would be "mydir"  It would check the absolute path against the chrootDir 
variable making sure they match.  So,  since mydir is relative it would 
need to find the PWD then append that and then construct the path 
confirm that that directory is really there and then parse the first 
part of the absolute path and compare it to chrootDir.  If they match 
and there are no '..' in the argument, this prevents getting around the 
problem, Or perhaps you figure out the ..'s and .'s when making the 
absolute path, you then pass the command onto the really cd command and 
execute it for the user. 

This could be done for ls and other programs you would like to allow the 
user but not allow them to leave their home directory.  Would be nice to 
have cd and ls and other basic commands know when they are running as 
rcd or rls like rbash works but this solution seems like it would work. 

Thoughts?  Has this been tried and it is too easy to get around? 

If someone is super cleaver and wants to pump this out that would be 
cool.  If not I'll work on it after the weekend, I'll be gone this 
weekend avoiding this 100 degree weather as much as I can. 

Thanks and have a great weekend.

Josh

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Jul 22 08:14:57 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 22 Jul 2006 08:14:57 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Off Topic: Moving to Portland
In-Reply-To: <44C23772.1030900@openboxbuilder.com>
References: <44C23772.1030900@openboxbuilder.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607220805410.22626@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 22 Jul 2006, Edward Terry wrote:

> I'm moving to Portland (from Georgia) at the end of August.  I've never
> been to Oregon and don't know much about it (beyond the results of a
> Google search), so I wondered if anyone could offer advice.

Edward,

   It rains quite a bit here, from September through May with other rainy days
to keep the natives from feeling restless. Get shoes with rubber soles, or a
good pair of rubber overshoes. Or, wear sandels all year; the water will
drain quickly from them.

> I'm about to start looking for a two-bedroom apartment.  I'll be working
> near Portland State University, so something close by would be ideal.
> Looking at the map, though, I wondered if that area floods very often. How
> much trouble does Portland have with flooding?  Should I look for high
> ground?  :-) Is there anything else (or anywhere else) I should look for
> or avoid?

   I never lived in downtown Portland, the closest was about 3 miles away in
the northeast section of town. Others will have to tell you about apartment
life and the city core. However, public transportation can be a good deal so
consider expanding the geographic radius of your search for living
accommodations.

   The closest we came to flooding was in February 1996 when we had a 100
year storm event. But, folks turned out to raise the height of the seawall
along the Willamette River with plywood sheets and sandbags. Starting in the
1930s, the Army Corps of Engineers followed instructions from Congress to
build flood control dams in the basin. There are now 13 such dams,
specifically to prevent the flooding that historically dampened the flood
plains, but tended to tork people living on them. However, if flooding is a
concern, get an apartment on an upper floor.

   Portland is the cleanest city in which I have lived; it's also the nicest
by any measure. The coast is 90 miles to the west; the mountains and high
desert just a bit more than that to the east. There's something for everyone
here, and it's a fine place to live and work.

Rich

Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc.(TM)    |            Accelerator
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>     Voice: 503-667-4517      Fax: 503-667-8863


From nsxfreddy at gmail.com  Sat Jul 22 08:48:54 2006
From: nsxfreddy at gmail.com (Jason R. Martin)
Date: Sat, 22 Jul 2006 08:48:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Encrypted data pass-phrase
In-Reply-To: <44BFC13E.4060105@acm.org>
References: <44BFC13E.4060105@acm.org>
Message-ID: <c29537840607220848w4895564ei21448d4133f74dcd@mail.gmail.com>

On 7/20/06, Roderick A. Anderson <raanders at acm.org> wrote:
> If that isn't vague enough I'll try to confuse it some more with details.
>
> I'm working on a system that needs to run charges against customers
> credit cards periodically or sporadically.  This will typically be more
> than one card at a time at a time and could happen anywhere from once a
> year to twice a day.
>
> The CC numbers are encrypted before being stored.
>
> We'd prefer to not have someone sitting at the console :-) entering the
> pass-phrase for each run.
>
> We've come up with several ideas how to make this fairly secure and
> hands-off but I have the impression several on the list have done
> something similar and might have other ( better ) ideas.

I don't have any specific recommendations.  However, I'll point out
that a false sense of security is worse than no sense of security.
Encryption is easily mis-used, and by its very nature gives a sense of
security that may or may not be deserved.  If the passphrase/key for
the encrypted data is stored on the same system as the encrypted data,
and that system is compromised, then there is no value added by the
encryption.

You may want to consider an independent security assessment of the
system before going live with anything.

Jason


From rsteff at comcast.net  Sat Jul 22 09:41:16 2006
From: rsteff at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sat, 22 Jul 2006 09:41:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Off Topic: Moving to Portland
In-Reply-To: <44C23772.1030900@openboxbuilder.com>
References: <44C23772.1030900@openboxbuilder.com>
Message-ID: <44C2552C.8020601@comcast.net>

Edward Terry wrote:

> How much trouble does Portland have with flooding?

Welcome to Oregon!

Everything Rich said plus:

PSU is up the hill from the river. If we get another 100 year flood, and 
if the enhanced seawall doesn't stop it, and if the water got as far as 
PSU you'd probably have worse things to worry about.

Oregon is a great place to live, especially if you like outdoor 
recreation. If you want some tourist advice, feel free to contact me off 
list and I'll share as much of my ex-tour guide stuff as you are willing 
to put up with. :-)

There is a large contingent of organized bicyclists in the Portland 
area. We have official bike lanes on many of the streets, and a few 
sections of some streets that are officially intended for very limited 
car traffic in favor of bicycles.

Rich mentioned the coast to the west and the mountains and high desert 
to the east. We also have the Mt. St. Helens volcano about 50 miles to 
the north and the Columbia River Gorge, the only near sea level pass 
through the western mountains in the western hemisphere.

About the weather: Rich mentioned rain from Sep - May. In the city, that 
stays as rain throughout the winter with only a couple of exceptions. 
One or two times a winter we might get an ice storm. When that happens, 
the city shuts down for a day or two, as far as traveling the streets 
goes. Then the ice melts and we're back to rain. Winter temps tend to 
run in the low 40's and summer temps in the 80's, this weekend not 
included -- 105 yesterday, 101 predicted for today! But when it gets 
hot, it's a dry heat. The only time it gets humid here is in the winter 
time.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

> run in the low 40's and summer temps in the 80's, this weekend not

Note, Portland is 50 miles inland from the coast, unlike most of the
large West Coast metropolitan. As a result Portland weather tends to be
more towards the extreme than other West Coast cities. This is minor
compared to what it is like on the East Coast though. Figure two weeks in
the 90s each year, and a week very close to 30 each year. During the rest
of Spring/Summer it will be around 70, the rest of Fall/Winter it will be
around 40. Also 1000 _hours_ of rain each year, that is merely 30 inches,
but it takes forever to come down.


>From: "Randy Stapilus" <stapilus at ridenbaugh.com>

This needs correction. Portland has good mass transit, if you're in
downtown. If you're at a very common destination then it is decent. If
you're going anywhere else Tri-Met (the public transit system) *sucks*,
with the only plus side being that it is pretty clean; that though isn't
the primary goal of a mass transit system. Specifically, in Beaverton or
Tigard you'll want a car unless you get very lucky and manage to be
directly on a bus route.

It is quite possible to always stay within downtown and thus avoid
Tri-Met's warts, but I'll have to rate Tri-Met pretty low due to lack of
coverage anywhere but downtown. Perhaps New York's system is pretty
dirty, but it will get you *anywhere* in New York *quickly*.

From johnxj at comcast.net  Sat Jul 22 22:54:26 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)

Subject: [PLUG] Backing up with tar

The need for caffeine while at the mall today drove me to the Starbucks
inside of Barnes and Noble. Naturally, I needed something to peruse
while sipping, so I grabbed several books on Linux, including a couple
about Ubuntu and a couple about command line stuff. One of the command
line books was Sobel, in which I read about using tar for backups.
However, the one I took home with me was the O'Reilly Linux Pocket
Guide. Now I'm sitting here at home trying to figure out tar. My
motivation is that Kdar still crashes a lot and I need something
more reliable. But I just need something for occasional backups of my
laptop to a USB pocket drive on an as-needed basis.

I've got the command down to this (manually adding today's date to the
filename): [Wait ... I bet I could automate that, right?]

tar -pczvf /media/usbdisk/backup_7_22_2006.tar.gz /home /etc

And I actually understand what all that is doing. Not only that, it
backs up 2.4 GB of data into a 1.1 GB tarball in 4 minutes 20 seconds
over a USB port. Pretty impressive. And it does it without crashing.
Kdar may soon be history around here.

But I have a few questions that google is not supplying answers for.

1) Does this command back up files that are open? In other words, had I
better close all open programs and files before running it?

2) The first time I ran it I did it as root (sudo), and then I noticed
that the resulting archive was owned by root. This might not be very
handy in case I need to access it as jjj. Any thoughts on this? The
files are just personal stuff that I don't want to lose. We're not
talking national defense archives here.

3) I have been trying to figure out relative path vs absolute path. My
understanding is that the / in /home and /etc means that in case of a
restore, that is where the files must go. The alternative (so my
googling tells me) is to leave off the /. But when I do that the
command pukes up: 
tar: home: Cannot stat: No such file or directory
tar: Error exit delayed from previous errors 
So I'm kind of confused. I need something where I can go into the
tarball and grab just one file that I inadvertently deleted from my
hard disk, and yet I might also need to restore the whole thing in case
of a hard disk crash, stolen laptop, etc. Relative path makes more
sense, doesn't it?

4) I'm also trying to figure out how to make it incremental. My best
guess is that I'm supposed to add -u to the command:

tar -pczvfu /media/usbdisk/backup_7_22_2006.tar.gz /home /etc

But when I try that it takes just as long as an entire backup. To test
it I opened my cheat-sheet file with Gedit, changed a couple of words
and resaved it. Then I ran the same exact command, except with the -u
switch. I assumed that it would cleverly go out to the existing
tarball, find the cheat-sheet.txt file, replace it, and suture the
thing back up again all nice and tidy. Instead the hard disk whirred
for 4 minutes and 20 seconds and the fan came on as the CPU shot from
800 MHz to 2.0 GHz, just as it does when I make a full backup without
the -u switch. The only difference is that I didn't get pages scrolling
by telling me what it was doing. Something tells me that the -u switch
is not what I should be doing in order to make an incremental backup.
Shouldn't I be making a different backup tarball file, i.e., a
different filename?

5) Clearly I need to back up the entire /home folder. And I have read
that /etc should be included as well. But are there other folders that
I should include? How about the /boot folder?

That's enough questions for one day. Now I need to go learn how to
restore a file.

On Sat, 2006-07-22 at 22:54 -0700, John Jason Jordan wrote:
snip
> I've got the command down to this (manually adding today's date to the
> filename): [Wait ... I bet I could automate that, right?]
> 
> tar -pczvf /media/usbdisk/backup_7_22_2006.tar.gz /home /etc
snip
> 
> But I have a few questions that google is not supplying answers for.

First, the popular option is rsync. If you back up frequently, it
overwrites only those files that have changed, saving a lot of t
> 
> 1) Does this command back up files that are open? In other words, had I
> better close all open programs and files before running it?
It should, to your last saved state. (i.e., you'll lose changes that
you're making after your last save)

> 2) The first time I ran it I did it as root (sudo), and then I noticed
> that the resulting archive was owned by root. This might not be very
> handy in case I need to access it as jjj. Any thoughts on this? The
> files are just personal stuff that I don't want to lose. We're not
> talking national defense archives here.

You should be fine - test a small bit of your backup. When you restore,
you should have file ownership by the original users and groups.

> 3) I have been trying to figure out relative path vs absolute path. 
snip

If you use relative path to backup, you need to be disciplined when you
restore, otherwise, you might end up with restored files
in /home/john/home/john directories.

> 4) I'm also trying to figure out how to make it incremental. My best
> guess is that I'm supposed to add -u to the command:

That's one reason why rsync is more popular. You can also rsync over
ssh, which makes it easier to back up securely.

> 5) Clearly I need to back up the entire /home folder. And I have read
> that /etc should be included as well. But are there other folders that
> I should include? How about the /boot folder?

In principle, if you're not backing up an entire hard drive, you need to
back up those files which you've changed personally.

If there's a crash, you can reinstall your version of Linux, and connect
to restore any additional updates (including kernel updates
to /boot). /home and /etc in general cover this. However, if you
recompile your own kernel (or have a dual-boot), backing up /boot is a
good idea.

> That's enough questions for one day. Now I need to go learn how to
> restore a file. 

Post again when you do.

Thanks,
Mike



From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Sun Jul 23 09:35:52 2006
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Sun, 23 Jul 2006 10:35:52 -0600 (MDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Backing up with tar
In-Reply-To: <20060722225426.f019c678.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060722225426.f019c678.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607230957430.9101@sphinktoo.pippiandcarlos.com>

Comments inline.

Carlos Konstanski

On Sat, 22 Jul 2006, John Jason Jordan wrote:

> Date: Sat, 22 Jul 2006 22:54:26 -0700
> From: John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net>
> Reply-To: "General Linux/UNIX discussion and help;	civil and on-topic"
>     <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
> To: PLUG <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
> Subject: [PLUG] Backing up with tar
> 
> The need for caffeine while at the mall today drove me to the Starbucks
> inside of Barnes and Noble. Naturally, I needed something to peruse
> while sipping, so I grabbed several books on Linux, including a couple
> about Ubuntu and a couple about command line stuff. One of the command
> line books was Sobel, in which I read about using tar for backups.
> However, the one I took home with me was the O'Reilly Linux Pocket
> Guide. Now I'm sitting here at home trying to figure out tar. My
> motivation is that Kdar still crashes a lot and I need something
> more reliable. But I just need something for occasional backups of my
> laptop to a USB pocket drive on an as-needed basis.
>
> I've got the command down to this (manually adding today's date to the
> filename): [Wait ... I bet I could automate that, right?]
>
> tar -pczvf /media/usbdisk/backup_7_22_2006.tar.gz /home /etc

Use backticks to run a date command inline:

     tar -pczvf /media/usbdisk/backup_`date --iso-8601`.tar.gz /home /etc

>
> And I actually understand what all that is doing. Not only that, it
> backs up 2.4 GB of data into a 1.1 GB tarball in 4 minutes 20 seconds
> over a USB port. Pretty impressive. And it does it without crashing.
> Kdar may soon be history around here.
>
> But I have a few questions that google is not supplying answers for.
>
> 1) Does this command back up files that are open? In other words, had I
> better close all open programs and files before running it?

I'm no authority on this subject, but I believe that linux does not have
all the weird "open file" issues that, say, winblows has.  In linux,
when you "open" a file (especially an executable), you are making an
in-memory copy of the file and using that.  Anyway, I have never had an
issue backing up an "open" file in linux (using tar or rsync) and
restoring it successfully.

I hope I'm wrong about what I said about open files in linux, and a real
expert will step up and provide us all with the real scoop.

>
> 2) The first time I ran it I did it as root (sudo), and then I noticed
> that the resulting archive was owned by root. This might not be very
> handy in case I need to access it as jjj. Any thoughts on this? The
> files are just personal stuff that I don't want to lose. We're not
> talking national defense archives here.

If you are backing up /etc (or any file/folder owned by someone other
thatn jjj), you need to run the tar command as root, and the resulting
file will be owned by root.  If you are putting the tarball on a USB
drive, don't you have to be root to mount it anyway (unless you are
using user permissions in /etc/fstab)?

>
> 3) I have been trying to figure out relative path vs absolute path. My
> understanding is that the / in /home and /etc means that in case of a
> restore, that is where the files must go. The alternative (so my
> googling tells me) is to leave off the /. But when I do that the
> command pukes up:
> tar: home: Cannot stat: No such file or directory
> tar: Error exit delayed from previous errors
> So I'm kind of confused. I need something where I can go into the
> tarball and grab just one file that I inadvertently deleted from my
> hard disk, and yet I might also need to restore the whole thing in case
> of a hard disk crash, stolen laptop, etc. Relative path makes more
> sense, doesn't it?

Because your tar command refers to the source and destination paths in
absolute terms, you can run the command from anywhere.  But, if you
inspect the resulting tarball, you will find that there are no absolute
paths stored in it.  This is a security feature, designed to make it
impossible for someone without access to a restricted directory (like
/etc) to be able to plant files there by untarring a tarball from, say,
their home directory.

It would be less ambiguous if you did away with absolute paths
altogether, and did something like this:

     su -
     cd /
     tar -pczvf media/usbdisk/backup_`date --iso-8601`.tar.gz home etc

You are getting the "tar: home: Cannot stat: No such file or directory"
error because you are trying to find the folder "home" from somewhere
other than /.

>
> 4) I'm also trying to figure out how to make it incremental. My best
> guess is that I'm supposed to add -u to the command:
>
> tar -pczvfu /media/usbdisk/backup_7_22_2006.tar.gz /home /etc
>
> But when I try that it takes just as long as an entire backup. To test
> it I opened my cheat-sheet file with Gedit, changed a couple of words
> and resaved it. Then I ran the same exact command, except with the -u
> switch. I assumed that it would cleverly go out to the existing
> tarball, find the cheat-sheet.txt file, replace it, and suture the
> thing back up again all nice and tidy. Instead the hard disk whirred
> for 4 minutes and 20 seconds and the fan came on as the CPU shot from
> 800 MHz to 2.0 GHz, just as it does when I make a full backup without
> the -u switch. The only difference is that I didn't get pages scrolling
> by telling me what it was doing. Something tells me that the -u switch
> is not what I should be doing in order to make an incremental backup.
> Shouldn't I be making a different backup tarball file, i.e., a
> different filename?
>
> 5) Clearly I need to back up the entire /home folder. And I have read
> that /etc should be included as well. But are there other folders that
> I should include? How about the /boot folder?

If you want to backup the entire machine, grab everything except /proc.
This goes for using rsync as well.

I have trouble getting --exclude to work with tar.  But I have good
success with --exclude-from .  In other words, I cannot specify which
paths to exclude in the tar command itself, but I can make a file
listing the excludes, and the tar command will read it.  Here's an
example exclude file:

root at ns:/hda1/sphinktoo# cat exclude 
./proc
./backup
./var/samba/public/avi
./var/samba/public/mp3
./tmp
./var/tmp/portage

Notice I exclude /proc, /tmp and /var/tmp/portage because nothing in
these directories needs to be restored in order to rescue a system
(/var/tmp/portage is a gentoo-specific path).  I also exclude /backup,
which is the place I am creating the tarball, so that no recursive
loops happen.  Finally, the remaining 2 directories have huge files
that are not critical, so I don't bother tarring those.

The command I use to tar my system:

     cd / ; \
     rm backup/*.bz2 ; \
     tar -jcvf backup/sphinktoo.tar.bz2 --exclude-from=backup/exclude .

In my case, /backup is an NFS share.  This is how I get the tarball
off the machine I'm backing up - no 2-step process needed.  tar works
great over any network filesystem mount.

>
> That's enough questions for one day. Now I need to go learn how to
> restore a file.

Final note on tar vs. rsync:

tar                             rsync
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Smaller backup image            Larger backup image (0% compression)

Takes a long time               Very fast

Not incremental                 Incremental to the extreme

Restoring single files: a pain  Restoring single files: a snap

Using remote repository         Using remote repository requires
   requires network filesystem     no network filesystem mount - ssh
   mount                           support built in
--------------------------------------------------------------------

For regular backups, I use tar due to the smaller storage footprint.  If
I am about to do something dodgy to my system, I will get an rsync
backup first because it's easier to use during an actual restore.

What would an rsync equivalent to my tar command look like?  (Notice I'm
not using the NFS mount here; I'm going straight to the server with
ssh.)

rsync -e ssh -av --progress --delete --exclude=/proc --exclude=/backup --exclude=/var/samba/public/avi --exclude=/var/samba/public/mp3 --exclude=/tmp --exclude=/var/tmp/portage / root at ns:/hda1/sphinktoo/rsync

Don't let me talk you out of a good thing.  tar is a very solid backup
mechanism.  http://www.kernel.org, Gentoo Linux and Cygwin use bzips to
distribute their product.  I've switched to bzips after several years
of happily using rsync, mostly for the disk space savings.  If you have
the disk space, though, rsync has its advantages.  It's definitely worth
being familiar with both utilities.

Happy data shepherding!

Carlos Konstanski

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Jul 23 14:00:56 2006
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun, 23 Jul 2006 14:00:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Off Topic: Moving to Portland
In-Reply-To: <20060723140540.BD2FC4751@ulke.nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200607232100.k6NL0usB035329@m5p.com>

>From: Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com>
> The land use patterns of the suburbs are hardly Trimet's fault.  When
> Beaverton and Tigard achieve the population density of NY, I'm sure
> Trimet's service levels will be there.  

I'm not. Tri-Met is very much centered on downtown. Service level doesn't
correspond very with the population density. Though downtown might have
four times the population density of further out, downtown certainly has
a lot more than four times the bus service! The irony of course is that
by the very nature of being spread out, outside downtown needs more bus
service than raw population would suggest because people *have* to go
further.

You should note that MAX isn't very efficient. They're absolutely fixed
at two car trains due to being at the level of surface streets. NY can
have trains more than 10 cars long, longer than some of the subway
stations by the nature of being underground. If you're going through
downtown, heading for the Zoo, Memorial Coliseum, Lloyd Center, or the
airport, MAX is also highly inefficient because it has zillions of
intermediate stops in downtown that aren't needed and greatly slow things
down.

For MAX to truely act as a backbone, the bus routes need to reflect that
as well. Most routes still go downtown like that was the center of the
universe, even when they're quite close to MAX.

> SE, NE, as well as close-in SW and NW all have good bus and light rail
> coverage and frequency.  You don't have to live downtown to make
> effective use of the system.  And how many places in the country can you
> get real-time arrival information from your browser or cell phone?

Yeah, but I'd rather have more buses and not care about whether the next
one was 5 minutes or 10 minutes away. Close in SW isn't too good. If
you're in the hills (which is pretty close in) there are severl holes 2
miles or more across.


>From: alan <alan at clueserver.org>
> Tri-Met is a hell of a lot better than some places.  Try getting anywhere 
> on a bus across the river in Vancouver, for example.  (Bonus points if it 
> is after 9pm or on a weekend.)
> 
> It is not perfect, but what is?

Yeah, transit agencies don't tend to handle talking to each other very
well. This is also Vancouver's fault though. The original plans for the
North-South line of MAX had it going across the river. The funding
was mostly lined up, and it was killed by Vancouver.

On Sun, 23 Jul 2006 19:12:04 -0400
Edward Terry <eterry at openboxbuilder.com> dijo:

> Does anyone know if a non-student can get a library card at PSU?  (Or at
> one of the other universities in the Portland area, for that matter.)
> I've lived near several universities; some allow members of the
> community to purchase library cards, while others won't even allow
> non-students in the door.

I don't think so, although anyone can use the library. The only
limitations are that the public can't check out books, rent study
rooms, or use the computer lab. However, you can access the Vikat
catalog even from your home, student or not. Just go to
http://www.pdx.edu/library/. Also, as far as I know, the staff would be
more than happy to answer questions and assist you, even if you are not
a student. I'm always asking a staff person how to find something, and
no one has ever asked me for my student ID before helping me.

Having said all that, you can enroll as a PSU student for $10. I think
you have to register for at least one course before you get library
privileges, though.

Another option would be to enroll at a different school that offers a
library card with fewer requirements (maybe one of the community
colleges). There is an inter-library deal where each school will honor
the other's library card. I can check out books from just about any
school in the northwest. 

Oh, and it's not really a library card. It's just encoded in the
magnetic strip on your student ID card. At least, that's the way it is
at PSU.

Library cards are given on an individual basis. I know that I can check 
out library books from CCC using my Oregon City Library Card. Also, 
there is an "inter-library loan" program that allows you to check out 
books from other libraries from your local library. The loans allow you 
to pick up and drop off a loaned book from your local library with out 
driving clear out to gresham or beaverton or where ever.

On Sun, 23 Jul 2006 20:09:42 -0700
Brian Beattie <beattie at beattie-home.net> dijo:

> Well depending on what you want to check out, the Central Branch of the
> Multnomah County Library is downtown, not all that far from PSU.

True, and anyone can get a Multnomah County Library card with just a
driver's license for ID. However, Multnomah County Library is not part
of the university inter-library deal. They won't honor my PSU student
ID and school libraries will not honor a Multnomah County Library card.
They're also more on the popular side; not so good if you want
advanced technical info. They live in a different world than the
university library system. Through the PSU library I can get just about
anything that has ever been printed because they will query every
university library in the known universe and obtain it for me. It may
come from deep in the third underground level of stacks at the
University of Lower Slobovistan and take a month to arrive, but if it's
out there, I can get it. Multnomah County just deals with other city,
county and state libraries. Not that I want to knock them -- they play
a vital role in society. Just not very useful past the high school
level of inquiry.

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Mon Jul 24 08:10:58 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Mon, 24 Jul 2006 08:10:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] iptables accounting question
In-Reply-To: <20060723132245.58be7f7d@badger.had1.or.comcast.net.>
References: <20060723132245.58be7f7d@badger.had1.or.comcast.net.>
Message-ID: <44C4E302.8070207@foo-projects.org>

Russ (YAR) Gilman-Hunt wrote:
> I have a pretty easy question to answer, but it's for a production
> firewall in front of about 800 IP addresses.
> 
> If I want to do some basic accounting on an IP address basis, is the
> best (quickest) way to do this by inserting an empty rule for each ip
> address for which I want statistics? Then I can use "iptables -L -v "
> and show all the packet counts /byte counts for each rule ?

it's by far the fastest way - the device doesn't go into promiscuous mode and 
nothing can count as fast as x_tables/ip_tables can in Linux afaik

> Should I insert a rule for each class-c, and then insert the accounting
> rules into those, to keep traversal time down?

I honestly doubt that this is a problem yet, but there's only one way to find 
out - give it a try. I don't think 800 entries is enough to make it spend a 
lot of time in traversal yet.

> and then on the other hand doing a dump-and-save procedure, which I can
> come up with, I'm just looking for a "quick and painless" way to tell
> someone "yeah, this ip address used 432 MB last month..." and/or make
> some pretty graphs and stuff.

iptables -L -Z is your friend, it displays all counters and then zeroes them, 
making it unnecessary to reload your configuration. Parse the output with awk 
hourly and you should be able to make nice graphs, which I've done this way.

Cheers,

Auke

Largest number of book stores and movie screens per capita.

Chris Dawson wrote:
> This worked for me using rbash:
>
> Create an account where login shell is rbash.  Create a .bashrc like
> this in the user's home directory:
>
> PATH=/opt/wiab/binary_data/upload/bin
> PS1='Master Upload #
>
> I symlinked only the applications I wanted into
> /opt/wiab/binary_data/upload/bin.  You can only run those applications
> when you are logged in.
>
> Chris
>
> On 7/21/06, Tim Slighter <tcslighter at gmail.com> wrote:
>> The rbash idea is a good one but there are still many more steps to 
>> take to
>> make sure the user stays within that shell and within the confines of 
>> their
>> home directory.  You have to create a directory somewhere like 
>> /usr/progs
>> and put the binaries and only the binaries that you want the user to 
>> have
>> access to and then declare that directory and the users only path in 
>> their
>> .bash_profile or .bashrc or both.  Better off if any programs with 
>> potential
>> shell escapes like pine, vi, emacs etc, are all replaced with a 
>> restricted
>> version of the binary such as rvi or rvim, etc.  You will also need to

>> other shells so declare an alias for ksh to /bin/rbash and csh ->
>> /bin/rbash, so what you are doing here is making sure that any shell 
>> they
>> attempt to get to will always put them back into and keep them in rbash.

From dalez at zeutenhorst.com  Fri Jul 21 23:29:58 2006

Edward Terry wrote:
>
> I don't know if the wording has changed, but Novell's policies have 
> not.  I asked SUSE about this before their acquisition.  Later, after 
> openSUSE was announced, I asked them if it had changed.  SUSE, 
> including openSUSE, cannot be resold (whether standalone, as part of a 
> software bundle, or preloaded on a system) without paying per copy.  
> Before the acquisition, SUSE required purchase of the actual boxed 
> product for resale (at least for small resellers).  Now, Novell will 
> allow resellers to burn their own media, but they must still pay on a 
> per-copy basis.
>
> Mandriva has similar requirements.  Fedora can be sold free of charge.
>
> Edward
>
Actually the Mandriva License says that you can freely distribute the 
down load editions but must pay to distribute of the commercial editions 
(like the Power Pack).  To resell or modify Mandriva, there is an 
agreement that you need to sign regarding their logos and intellectual 
property and their liability (or lack there of).  You can avoid the 
agreement if you remove Mandriva's logos and name from the product.  
Mandriva also many levels of partners and various other commercial 
agreements. 

Dale





From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sun Jul 23 19:54:55 2006
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)
Date: Sun, 23 Jul 2006 19:54:55 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Looking back...
Message-ID: <1153709695.44c4367f95682@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

August 1990, Rainbow color computer magazine.

"The Future of the CoCo," by William Barden Jr.

"There's no point in  denying it, MS-DOS systems
such as the Tandy 1000 series and  IBM PS/2 are
big business.  They consitute the bulk of computer
sales all over the world..."

He compares DOS's 640k of memory to a CoCo 3's 512k.

He says that the IBM's 640x200 CGA monitor is comparable
to 640 x 192 on a color computer CM-8 monitor.

He sets the price of the IBM at $1200 equipped and says
a comparable color computer would cost $750.

"...Multi-Pak interface for many of these...  CoCo options 
are generally a third to half the cost of a comparable 
option on an MS-DOS system..."

"...Software is another factor in computing the two types
of systems.   There's a great deal of software for MS-DOS
systems; however, the CoCo also has a large amount of 
reasonably priced software for basic applications. - data
communications, spreadsheets, wordprocessing, and the
like.  Again, CoCo software is much less expensive                             
                                           
than the MS-DOS variety - about one-third to one-half the
cost."

...

"BASIC still remains the most popular computer language.  BASIC
is bundled with most computers as part of the system software.
Fortunately for the computing community, BASIC used with all
MS-DOS systems and with the CoCo is Microsoft BASIC.  I'm not
a big fan of monopolies in computer software, but in this case
Microsoft basic has standardized BASIC programming."

"The 80x86 instruction set...  is a hodge-podge of instructions
that date back to one of the original Intel microprocessors, the
8008."

He briefly mentions that Windows 3.0 has just come out claiming
that OS/2 and OS-9 are more interesting, especially when you add
BASIC09.

All efforts to carry on after the coco 3 failed essentially.  If
you go to http://www.cloud9.net/, you may be able to support a
hobby level interest in color computers.   Overall though 16
years later, the color computer is essentially dead.  You can't
even buy floppy disks for them anymore let alone upgrade to a
modern and compatible variant.  If I'm not mistaken, the IBM PC 
has been around for about 26 years.  For 10 of those years, there
was the color computer.  Today, Intel even makes the processors
in Macs, the only surviving large volume IBM PC competitor.   
Games are increasingly becoming tied to restrictive gaming systems 
that their makers try to purposely hobble so you can't use them 
for personal computing, XBOX for example.

The Tomcat was a bust along with the MM1.  I don't know if there
were any other major attempts to clone the color computer with
a faster more powerful machine.  Why these efforts failed, I'm
not certain.

Regards,

Michael C. Robinson

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Jul 24 11:38:34 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 24 Jul 2006 11:38:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OK, now I did it. Deleted /bin
Message-ID: <20060724113834.ac8cf5b1.johnxj@comcast.net>

The computer is still running.

I have two installations of Dapper-64. One is plain, bare installation on hda2, which is 60 GB (hda1 is swap). The second installation is the real one, on hda3 (8 GB). I have been tweaking, testing and installing on the second one (the hda3 installation). My plan was always to wipe out the first installation, then copy all files from the second installation to it so that my real installation would be on the 60 GB partition, leaving the second installation on the 8 GB partition as a rescue installation. Today I decided it was time to do so.

Both installations automatically mount the other's partition. So here I am running the second (real) installation, I opened Nautilus to display hda2, and I see all its files and folders. So far, so good. I wanted to delete them all. Then I thought I would use rsync to copy everything from this real installation to hda2, replacing all the deleted files.

However, I ran into a problem. I couldn't delete anything. Permissions and ownerships, of course. OK, to heck with Nautilus. I opened terminal window and navigated to /media/hda2. Then I tried sudo rmdir bin (thinking I would just start with the top one and work my way down). But this gave me an error message that the folder was not empty. After reading the --help I finally accomplished it with sudo rmdir -r /bin. While doring this I had the Nautilus window open showing hda2. And the bin folder disappeared. 

So then repeated, substituting "boot" for "bin." And this gave me "command not found." What? This worked a few seconds ago. 

Yep. That command deleted the bin folder from BOTH partitions. This, in spite of the fact that I was in jjj at Devil5:/media/hda2$ when I issued the command. 

OK, time to look at backups. Oops. All my backups so far have been just /home and /etc. I have no full disk image backup.

Wait ... once at a Clinic a couple months ago I replaced the original hard drive with a new one. Then I put the old one in a USB enclosure. It should still have the /bin folder. <Scrambling around, finding drive and its cable.> OK, it's plugged in. Nautilus sees it as "54.9 GB Volume." But double-clicking on it gives me an error message "Unable to mount the volume, unable to execute pmount." OK, it's probably not listed in fstab. My other USB drive is still connected and mounted at /media/usbdisk. I'll unmount both, then plug in just the old one. Hopefully Dapper will see it as a USB drive that it can mount at /dev/usbdisk. 

Oops. "Unable to unmount." OK, never mind. I can unmount the things. Because, push come to shove, my fingers are more powerful than the computer. I waited a few moments and made sure no lights were flickering, then pulled them out. They disappeared from Nautilus. Then I plugged in just the old one. Didn't work. Shows up in Nautilus, but same error message about not being able to execute pmount. OK -- wild guess here -- pmount is a utility located in /bin. <Sigh>

OK, no problem, back to the command line. Opened the terminal window where I caused this mess. Decided to do "dmesg | tail" to see what the drive is called. When I hit enter, a message popped up "Gnome terminal has quit unexpectedly." I clicked on restart. Got the same error message. Several more times, same error message. Terminal will not run. From creswick at gmail.com  Mon Jul 24 13:10:20 2006
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon, 24 Jul 2006 13:10:20 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OK, now I did it. Deleted /bin
In-Reply-To: <20060724113834.ac8cf5b1.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060724113834.ac8cf5b1.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <c834ec80607241310g57420e93i6efabdea6010b0ae@mail.gmail.com>

On 7/24/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> OK, computer is still running, but I'm out of ideas. I still have
> 10 GB unused on the hard disk. I can shut down, make a
> fresh install of Dapper on it, then copy its /bin folder to the
> others. It appears that's the only way I can get /bin back.
> We'll see if Sylpheed can still send an e-mail. If so, I'll wait
> for an hour or so to see if there is a guru on the list with a
> better, simpler suggestion.
>

As has already been pointed out, /dev/hda2 *should* still have a /bin
directory.  However, that may not be critical one way or the other.
I'd suggest booting off an ubuntu64-live disk -- ideally the live cd
that corresponds to the install disk you used to install dapper.  When
that boots you should be able to 1) look at hda2 and hda3 to see which
if any have a a /bin directory. 2) copy a bin directory over to hda2
and/or hda3 from one of three locations: hda2, hda3 or the cd's
filesystem.  (when you boot up with the live cd this will show up as
"/bin", whereas the hda2 bin dir, if it exists will probably be at
"/mnt/hda2/bin" or "/media/hda2/bin" or some such place.)

To do the copy, you need to first find the mounted location of the
destination -- this is the place you need a /bin dir.  Either hda2 or
hda3.  Since I don't know exactly where these will be mounted, or even
if they will be mounted by default, you will have to poke around a
bit.   The first step is to run "mount" and see if they show up.  If
they do, you will see the mount point in the output also.  Let's
assume you want the bin dir on hda3, and hda3 is mounted at /mnt/hda3.

Go to a terminal and run:

sudo cp -a /bin /mnt/hda3

That should restore your bin dir to hda3, and you *should* be able to
reboot into your "workable" 8-gig partition. The next step is to
restore any programs in /dev/hda3's bin dir that were not on the live
cd.  I don't know how to do this :( but I'm sure some one else on here
does..

Once this is all ironed out I'd suggest using a live cd to do the copy
over to the new partition.  (may be worthwhile to format the 60 gig
drive before putting data on it, so you don't get confused about what
has been copied and what was there from the previous partition.)

--Rogan

let me get this straight:

1) you had 2 full installations (hda2, hda3)
2) one of them is broken (hda2)
3) the system boots/runs the broken one

All you need in this case is to manually reboot into the still intact 
installation. That's as easy as booting `linux init=/bin/sh root=/dev/hda3` 
assuming hda3 is the intact installation. After that you can mount && cp all 
the stuff from the intact /bin to the broken install, and reboot back into it.

Cheers,

Auke

> > 2) one of them is broken (hda2)

>
> As far as I know, both are broken. That's because I deleted the /bin

That's extremely unlikely, as you would have to be mounting *two* 
folders with /bin in them, at the same place.... or, alternately, you 
only ever had *one* bin folder.

But doing it live like this is more fun, and more of a challenge. :-)

Since /bin is gone, you can (or rather, must?) use tools from /usr/bin 
and /usr/sbin (and /usr/local/bin, etc. etc.) to find and get your /bin/ 
tools back. Thankfully, that's a *lot* of tools at your disposal.... and 
find (the command) can happily help you get to the "other" bin, if it 
still exists... how far have you gotten? Do you have a working terminal 
yet, or do you need to make a new user entry, with a shell that *isn't* 
a shell from /bin?

-Ronabop
