On 7/24/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> On Mon, 24 Jul 2006 13:10:20 -0700
> "Rogan Creswick" <creswick at gmail.com> dijo:
>
> > As has already been pointed out, /dev/hda2 *should* still have a /bin
> > directory.  However, that may not be critical one way or the other.
> > I'd suggest booting off an ubuntu64-live disk
>
> Great suggestion! I hadn't thought of that! Wait ... I think the Ubuntu
> live/install CD (I actually burned a live/install DVD, which is what I
> used for both installations) does not let you touch the filesystem. I
> am told that Knoppix will, but this is 64-bit Dapper, so Knoppix won't
> work.

I really think the live disk is the easiest way to do this.  As you've
already seen, many, many things rely on stuff in /bin.  Doing anything
is going to be chancy (I don't mean that you will do more damage, just
that many things won't work, and you  probably won't know which things
are broken until you try them all.. which will take forever.)

The Ubuntu live cd may not let you touch the filesystem by default,
but you can unmount them and re-mount them read-write so that you can.
 The other resuce disk may be easier, but you should know that it is
indeed possible to do this with an ubuntu live cd (barring any very
bizare and arcane configurations on the ubuntu disk).

The following commands should do this (run as root, or with sudo,
also, tihs is in context of an ubuntu live distro):

umount /dev/hda2
umount /dev/hda3

mkdir /mnt/hda2
mount /dev/hda2 /mnt/hda2

mkdir /mnt/hda3
mount /dev/hda3 /mnt/hda3

(the mount commands may need a -o rw, as in:
mount -o rw /dev/hda3 /mnt/hda3)

> > Go to a terminal and run:
>
> Terminal won't run, and I can't log in when I do Ctrl-Alt-F1. At the
> moment I'm stuck with the GUI stuff.

Hence the rescue disk.  First step in reparing a system: Get a
terminal (if at all possible) :)

In a later email in this thread you mention:

> It looks like I will have to reinstall everything I have done in the
> past two months since the new hard disk was installed. And that's
> assuming I can get the /bin folder off the old hard disk back onto
> hda3. Also, there was at least one kernel update since then. (I use
> Upgrade Manager once a week or so.)

This should not be a time consuming or difficult task -- the database
of applications you've installed is still intact.  In the worst case,
once you have a /bin back on your system, you can do this:

dpkg --get-selections > packages

then use the packages file on a new install of Dapper 64 as:

dpkg --set-selections < packages

then:
apt-get update && apt-get upgrade

replace your /etc and /home from backups, and you're good to go.

It is possible to refresh all the packages with an apt or dpkg command
though.. (you could try doing the process I describe above, it may
very well work and it shouldn't hurt anything.)

apt-get's --reinstall option may help too.

--Rogan

I started by booting to my Ubuntu live/install DVD. Then I changed my

mounted the usbdisk, hda2 and hda3. Then I copied the contents ( -a )
of the usbdisk (really my old hard disk, not used for the past two
months) to /hda3/bin and to hda2/bin.

[Side comment: Some of us really, really, really need a course in how
to use the cp command. I don't mean just copying one file. I mean how
to get files from one folder into another folder without also creating
a subfolder. I have read how-tos on that until I am dizzy and I can't
ever get it right. I never get the / in the right place, or I use a /
when I shouldn't. It was easy in DOS: Go to a folder and type
"copy /folder/folder/*.* and it copied everything from that folder into
the one you were in. OK it was easy because I understood the rules. Why
is it that I cannot grasp the rules for Linux? Additional comment:
Don't reply by telling me how to do it. This is a problem that requires
hands-on practice; not reading a how-to. I need exercises.]

OK, back to the present.

Finally successfully copied /bin from the usbdisk to the two partitions
on the laptop hard disk, I shut down the Rescue CD and rebooted. Except
I forgot to unmount the hda2 and hda3 partitions first. Also forgot to
unmount and unplug the USB disk. See, once you start ***ing up, you
just keep on ***ing up. Computers know when you have ***ed up. They
purposely make it easy for you to continue ***ing up. Don't ever let a
Linux computer know you don't know what you are doing. Bad enough on a
Windows computer, but a Linux computer has no mercy.

When the Grub menu came up I decided to go for the gusto and boot
straight to hda3 (my real installation). I watched anxiously as it
proceeded, and then heaved a sigh of relief as it started to mount the
filesystem. Oh no! Not shut down clean, fsck forced. And it was hanging
trying to read the USB disk. I decided to abort. I held the power
button down until shut down. Then I pulled out the USB disk and
restarted.

This time things went much better. There was a forced fsck on both hda2
and hda3, but it went smoothly. But then I groaned as I saw the usual
messages replaced with command-line type. This always happens when the
video is borked. Sure enough, lots of video driver errors. But hey! It
booted to my normal installation at a command line! Plus, I had been
here with broken video several times before.

So I did "sudo nano /etc/X11/xorg.conf." (see, I even remembered where
the file was and what it was called), and proceeded to deleted "Nvidia"
and replace it with "nv" in the driver line. Then I restarted.

And when it rebooted, it came right up! No Nvidia video drivers, but I
can fix that later. So here I am. Everything looks exactly as before.
Sylpheed and Firefox are working. I'll deal with the others later.

A thousand thanks to all who helped today. Now I'm off to finish fixing
stuff. And first I'm going to mount my other USB disk, the one I use
for backups, and do an rsync of this whole bloody partition.

"un-do" the key swap for it to go back to normal.  i.e. Create
.Xmodmap for each login.

No link, per se.  We use loop-AES and have a bunch of scripts and
procedures we use to carefully encrypt a HDD, etc.  It's taken a while
to automate, and there's still some room for improvement -- as always.

satisfy Requirements 1-4, and more (their Windows XP laptops are also
encrypted).  Later, we ported this to several ditros, but found Arch
Linux to be the best platform to work with, overall:
http://www.archlinux.org/

The loop-AES README is a good place to start:
http://loop-aes.sourceforge.net/  When I have some time, I'll try to
write an article or two about this.  Sorry.  Happy to help, off-line,
though.

From christian at rocksolidservice.com  Wed Jul 26 08:53:37 2006
From: christian at rocksolidservice.com (Christian Bewley)
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 2006 08:53:37 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Graphic Format Quality
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607260825320.20594@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607260825320.20594@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <44C79001.5070807@rocksolidservice.com>

Rich,

What does the image look like when you print it? Does it look as crude 
as it is on the screen or is it a better quality?

<quote from http://www.prepressure.com/formats/eps/fileformat.htm >

EPS files can optionally contain a bitmapped image preview, so that 
systems that can't render PostScript directly can at least display a 
crude representation of what the graphic will look like.

There are 4 preview formats:

    * PICT, mainly used in files generated on Macs. The PICT file is
      stored in the resource fork of the EPS file, while the actual
      PostScript data are stored in the data fork. PICT is the default
      file format of QuickDraw, the graphics model that is used by all
      Mac applications to generate the screen display.
    * TIFF: Most EPS files created by Windows applications contain a
      TIFF file for preview purposes.
    * Metafile: Some EPS files originating on PC contain a Windows
      Metafile preview. WMF or Windows Metafile is the PC equivalent of
      the Macintosh PICT file format.
    * EPSI which is an EPS file with a platform device independent
      preview. EPSI is an all ASCII (no binary data or headers) version
      of EPS. EPSI provides for a hexadecimal encoded preview
      representation of the image that will be displayed or printed.
      EPSI files were documented by Adobe as a means of providing a
      preview for EPS files which would be cross-platform. In reality
      though DOS machines and Windows favour embedding TIFF or even
      Windows Metafiles in the PostScript. EPSI is mainly used on Unix
      systems.

</quote>

On 7/26/06, Richard C. Steffens <rsteff at comcast.net> wrote:
> After several hours away from my machine, i.e. it's running but idling,
> there is a delay of up to two or three seconds between clicking on a
> running program's button at the bottom of the screen and the display of
> that program's window. After a couple of minutes, response time returns
> to normal. This effect grows gradually over a period of weeks (maybe
> months?) to the point that it becomes annoying. I'm used to some delays
> getting a program started, but once running they usually run fine.
>
> Any ideas what causes this?

Is the delay from the applications being paged back in from swap?  Is
your hard drive grinding away while the delay occurs?  Perhaps a
background cron job (does SuSE ship with slocate/updatedb enabled?) is
hogging your memory causing your idle apps to be paged out?

Jason

Yikes! I've seen firefox/thunderbird alone eat 192M of RAM.

It's just swapping everything back in.. this is normal. Running KDE on a
PII is not very recommended :)

If you had more RAM and CPU, I'd suggest tuning the swappiness kernel
parameter, but I think you're just in need of more hardware. Even with a
light-weight window manager, I think you'll still experience this, but
probably not as bad.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jul 26 11:12:56 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 26 Jul 2006 11:12:56 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Graphic Format Quality
In-Reply-To: <44C79001.5070807@rocksolidservice.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607260825320.20594@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 26 Jul 2006, Christian Bewley wrote:

> What does the image look like when you print it? Does it look as crude as
> it is on the screen or is it a better quality?

   Since this is a family-oriented mail list, I'll limit my description to
"poor."

   But, ... I found the ideal solution! It's a tool called 'bmeps' (which I
deduced stands for 'bit-mapped to EPS', 'cause that's what it does. It will
convert a bit-mapped .png, .jpg, or similar file to .eps. And it does an
outstanding job of it. Took about 6 sec to configure, 1 sec to make, and a
short time to cp the executable to /usr/local/bin. Works like a charm.

                See: <http://bmeps.sourceforge.net/index.html>

   The resulting .eps was happily accepted by latex and dvips. I specified
the grey-scale option during the converstion, along with PostScript level 2,
and I really like the results.

Rich

A memory is returning: some years ago, when I had spare time, but just 
as it was about to disappear, I added memory to achieve 192 Mb. 
Somewhere around that time is also when I installed SuSE 9.1 on this 
machine. I expected the install process to totally reformat and 
partition the drive, but for some reason (either I said yes when I 
should have said no, or visa versa) the old partitions were kept. Later, 
I consolidated some of them and then added the second swap partition. 
IIRC, the first one is unused, but don't quote me on that. I believe the 
recommendation was to create a swap partition that is double the 
installed RAM, but don't quote me on that, either. Here's what fdisk has 
to say:

    Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
/dev/hda1   *           1          12       96358+  83  Linux
/dev/hda2              13        1027     8152987+   5  Extended
/dev/hda5              13          35      184716   82  Linux swap
/dev/hda6              36         521     3903763+  83  Linux
/dev/hda7             522         570      393561   82  Linux swap
/dev/hda8             571        1027     3670821   83  Linux

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jul 27 00:17:17 2006
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 27 Jul 2006 00:17:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Morning Slugishness
In-Reply-To: <20060726221301.GA22055@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <44C791F6.6040208@comcast.net>
	<c29537840607260944r70ff216em9b68e39834c6343b@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060726221301.GA22055@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <868xmfqzya.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> I wonder: Is there is some way to tell it to swap all the
Keith> desktop apps back in, after the heavy lifting is done?  Then
Keith> the machine would be ready to rock in the morning...

Yes.  I've mentioned this before:

  # swapoff -a
  # swapon -a

The first will page all the swapped out data back into RAM, the second
will re-enable swap.

And, in Keith's case it ought to be fairly easy to add the operation
to the end of his backup script.

Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''

Subject: [PLUG] Fun with IPTables
In-Reply-To: <55cf303a0607271411q23997964m1209433384c9aac@mail.gmail.com>
References: <55cf303a0607271411q23997964m1209433384c9aac@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <86mzatmu4r.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Alan" == Alan Olsen <alan.olsen at gmail.com> writes:

Alan> http://www.ex-parrot.com/~pete/upside-down-ternet.html 

Which begins: "My neighbours are stealing my wireless internet
access. I could encrypt it or alternately I could have fun."

Or, alternatively, you could decide to announce that it is
intentionally available for sharing.  See the Personal Telco Project,
for example:

  <http://www.personaltelco.net/>

With all the recent hoo-haw over the Unwire Portland (MetroFi)
project, it bares realizing that we could easily have vastly better
wireless network access than MetroFi can ever provide *this afternoon*
if people simply decided to affirmatively, intentionally share their
existing internet access.  Individually-deployed wireless is so dense
in Portland *today* that it's not even funny.  How powerful and
generally useful could it be if we all decided to share it?


-- 
Russell Senior, Secretary
russell at personaltelco.net

Some food for thought for the paranoid,  ever wondered if when you hop onto
someone's wireless network for free, do they have an entire arsenal of
sniffers hooked up on their wireless network and they are capturing all of
your traffic so it can be used later?  Last time I accidentally ended up on
someone else's wireless network without any authentication, wep, or mac
filtering and got a DHCP address, I started wondering, suppose this is a
trap or a home grown honey pot and they are harvesting sniffed passwords?

networks and toss the wireless stuff.

be an SSH tunnel, the less services running on your home system, the less
opportunity for people trying to find a way in.

Encryption is your friend.  (As is ssh tunneling.)

> On Fri, 28 Jul 2006, Tim Slighter wrote:

>> As for SSH tunnels, I beg to disagree and contend that there should not

>  Almost every day my sshd log shows folks -- primarily from Asia -- trying

Yeah. I use "denyhosts" to block those.  I got tired of the repeated 
attempts from the same servers over and over and over again.

If you configure ssh correctly, there should not be any security issues. 
Use public key, disable ssh v1, and remove cleartext passwords.

On 7/28/06, Tim Slighter <tcslighter at gmail.com> wrote:
> The real solution is to revert back to direct cable connection for home
> networks and toss the wireless stuff.

How does this prevent some one on the other end of the connection from
sniffing your password?  How do you know there are no malicious
monitors between your isp and your destination?  Wired networks aren't
really that much more secure than wireless.

> As for SSH tunnels, I beg to disagree and contend that there should not even
> be an SSH tunnel, the less services running on your home system, the less
> opportunity for people trying to find a way in.

Is an ssh tunnel really a service?  Isn't the standard practice to
make them local-only, and close the tunnel whenever you aren't
personally using it?  I fail to see how this is less secure than not
using encryption.

--Rogan

On Fri, 28 Jul 2006, Rogan Creswick wrote:

> On 7/28/06, Tim Slighter <tcslighter at gmail.com> wrote:
>> The real solution is to revert back to direct cable connection for home
>> networks and toss the wireless stuff.
>
> How does this prevent some one on the other end of the connection from
> sniffing your password?  How do you know there are no malicious
> monitors between your isp and your destination?  Wired networks aren't
> really that much more secure than wireless.

If you have a cable modem, the line is shared (and sniffable) by everyone 
on your block.

>> As for SSH tunnels, I beg to disagree and contend that there should not 
>> even
>> be an SSH tunnel, the less services running on your home system, the less
>> opportunity for people trying to find a way in.
>
> Is an ssh tunnel really a service?  Isn't the standard practice to
> make them local-only, and close the tunnel whenever you aren't
> personally using it?  I fail to see how this is less secure than not
> using encryption.

If you are routing through to your home machine and back out you are.  But 
if you set it up right, it is not insecure.

On Fri, 2006-07-28 at 12:15 -0700, Tim Slighter wrote:
> Some food for thought for the paranoid,  ever wondered if when you hop onto
> someone's wireless network for free, do they have an entire arsenal of
> sniffers hooked up on their wireless network and they are capturing all of
> your traffic so it can be used later?  Last time I accidentally ended up on
> someone else's wireless network without any authentication, wep, or mac

That's why all my traffic, except web browseing, is encrypted when using
wireless, even if it's not a honeypot, somebody with a sniffer could
capture all your traffic.  WEP is just to make bosses happy, not for
real security.

And I'd also recomend PTP style shareing, unless you have comcast, then
you propbably should turn your AP off when you ar not using it. :P

I'm not personally, but I'm almost certain that model is supported by HPLIP, which integrates with CUPS. From the web administration interface when you add the printer, if you select HP and the model you need isn't listed, I recommend installing HPLIP (HP Linux Imaging and Printing) through whatever system your distro provides for packages.

Ah, I've used the feature you speak of. I'm almost certain this feature is implemented by the driver itself in Windows, not anything printer-specific. However, I've not seen such a feature using HPLIP before. The Canon BJC-4400 Gutenprint driver has a setting for this, available in the CUPS web interface. If your driver had such a setting, that's where you'd find it.

I'm not an expert on printing, but it may be possible to print to a postscript file and use some nifty commandline tools to seperate each page into it's own file, then queue each individual file the same number of times.

I've seen lots of folks on the list reference the postscript tool suite, perhaps one of them knows how this would be possible, if it is.

From david.fleck at mchsi.com  Sat Jul 29 13:55:46 2006
From: david.fleck at mchsi.com (David Fleck)
Date: Sat, 29 Jul 2006 15:55:46 -0500 (CDT)
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS postscript/config problems
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0607260743430.7324@grond.sourballs.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0607260743430.7324@grond.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0607291550440.7324@grond.sourballs.org>

On Wed, 26 Jul 2006, David Fleck wrote:
> (Just to get it out of the way, I'll start by saying I loathe CUPS. 
> Printing used to be simple for me back in the lpd days - now it's a 
> byzantine pain in the ass.)
[...]

To respond to my own posting, I was able to solve this problem.  It turns 
out that the version of ghostscript (8.15.0) that OpenSuSE 10.0 installs 
can't handle certain postscript constructs (the developers considered them 
'nonstandard').  The answer was to upgrade to gs 8.15.2, and that seems to 
have solved that problem.

The second problem was a config error; the lesson learned, basically, was 
"don't filter output on the client machine and then filter it again on the 
print server machine".

--
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com

How do I know this? Because I have now accomplished it, just not with
the app I was trying to use.

I had been trying to print 100 copies collated of a 276 page book in
PDF format. I started trying to use Adobe Reader 7.08. I chose Adobe
Reader because Adobe Reader 7.0 on my Windows desktop does this without
a problem. But Reader 7.08 on Linux does not. It just continuously
concatenates print jobs to one mammoth spool file. You can imagine how
big the spool file would be. Plus, printing is slow, you don't get job
offset in the output stacker, etc. 

When I discovered that it didn't work, I tried the command line. First
I tried printing the PDF file directly. The command I used was "lp -d
Laserjet-8000 -n 2." (I started with two copies just to see if it would
work.) It printed one copy and stopped. I switched to "lpr -P
Laserjet-8000 -# 2." Got the same results. Then I tried putting the -n
in different places, but still no luck. Finally I installed two more
printers in CUPS, and repeated the commandline experiment. Still no
luck.

> I'm not an expert on printing, but it may be possible to print to a 
> postscript file and use some nifty commandline tools to seperate 
> each page into it's own file, then queue each individual file the same 
> number of times.

That was the next thing I tried. I used Adobe Reader 7.08 to print to a
PostScript file, then used the lp and lpr commands to print it. Still
no joy. Worse, Adobe Reader hosed a graphic on the first page by
deciding it was underneath the text when it was really on top. I didn't
bother to figure out why -- it didn't work anyway.

And then I decided to install other PDF viewers. I already had Evince,
but its print dialog is pathetic. Searching in Synaptic I found Kpdf,
and that was the secret. It happily prints multiple copies collated
just like Adobe Reader 7.0 does on my Windows desktop. That is, except
that the first copy out is unbearably slow. But at least it works. More
important, it proves where the problem lies. At least now I can quit
fiddling with CUPS, drivers, PPD files, and the command line.

> I've seen lots of folks on the list reference the postscript tool suite, 
> perhaps one of them knows how this would be possible, if it is.

Another thing to google on. 

Thanks for the suggestions. 


From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat Jul 29 11:46:00 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat, 29 Jul 2006 18:46:00 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] Laserjet 8000
In-Reply-To: <20060729130207.39e868b3.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060729110820.400cda41.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<200607291126.48203.aaron@madebyai.com>
	<20060729130207.39e868b3.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20060729184600.GA29594@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Sat, Jul 29, 2006 at 01:02:07PM -0700, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> On Sat, 29 Jul 2006 11:26:48 -0700
> Aaron Ten Clay <aaron at madebyai.com> dijo:
> 
> > On Saturday 29 July 2006 11:08, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> > > If anyone on this list is printing to a Laserjet 8000, I'd like to know which driver and setup you're using. 
> > > _______________________________________________
> > 
> > I'm not personally, but I'm almost certain that model is supported by HPLIP, which integrates with CUPS. From the web administration interface when you add the printer, if you select HP and the model you need isn't listed, I recommend installing HPLIP (HP Linux Imaging and Printing) through whatever system your distro provides for packages.
> 
> Thanks for the suggestion. Already have HPLIP installed. And several
> more related packages. And all the PPD files. And CUPS. 
> 
> I can print to it just fine. The problem is being unable to access a
> key feature of the printer that I need. The feature is printing
> multiple copies collated without concatenating individual print jobs to
> a massive spool file ("RIP once, print many"). I've spent hours and
> hours googling and experimenting. No luck so far. I can print to it
> with this feature just fine from my Windows 2000 desktop, which is
> using the same PPD file.
> 
> I am hoping to find someone who has accomplished this. 

The HPLJ 8000 is a Postscript printer, and that is probably the interface
that CUPS is using.   The postscript file itself, generated by the
application and merely transmitted by CUPS, is what tells the printer
to print multiple copies of a page, with a "/#copies 2 def" (replace 2
with desired count) in the file.  I suspect that Postscript will only
interpret that as printing multiple copies of each page at each
"showpage" command in the Postscript, without collation.

When you think about it, the printer would need a hell of a lot of
memory to store all the page images for a book, so all most printers
can do is concatenate multiple copies of the source Postscript in a
"massive spool file".   However, it looks like the HP8000 can have
an optional hard-disk, and could spool the whole images out
repetitively.  I don't know whether that hard disk is accessable
under Postscript, but the 8000 PPD file has some magic words like
"Mopy" and "HPOption_Disk" that may result in suitable Postscript.  
Google on them, and also ask questions on the linuxprinting.org
HP discussion forum, after searching for past answers of course.
Most of us do not have such printers.

If the printer is fast and the pages are simple, repeated spooling
of a whole-document image isn't too bad;  that is what happens when
you click the "collate" box for most Linux or Windows applications
with less capable printers.  However, you will need to have enough
room in /var/spool/cups or /var/spool/lpd to hold the monster.  If
you built /var in too small a partition, you can use symlinks to 
put the partition in a larger space.

Another option is to dump all the postscript from the application
into an appropriately named Postscript file, then build a shell
script with a loop around the lpr command to print out that file
repeatedly.  If I was in the print-on-demand book business, that
is what I would do, all driven from a web page order form that
selects the file and produces cover pages with UPS info ("hmm, the
printer is going, time to bind a cover and stuff an envelope and
summon UPS").  Sometimes, the Windows-style "everything through
the GUI" approach is far too time consuming...

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Sat, 29 Jul 2006, m0gely wrote:

> Luke Eckley wrote:
>> >  AOL flat blocks my mail.  It doesn't even get out of the queue. 
>> >  Yahoo junks it (and I think Hotmail, but I don't have an account 
>> >  to check), but gmail has no problem with it.
>>
>>  Are you sending mail directly? If so can you relay it through your
>>  ISP?
>
> Yes, directly.  But that's an incredibly simple fix to the problem. 
> I will give that a try in the morning.

I had to implement such a solution a long time ago in order to send 
e-mail to my parents. Using sendmail on Comcast, the config bits were 
pretty easy. In sendmail.mc,

   define(`SMART_HOST',`smtp:smtp.comcast.net')

Contrary to my expectations, Comcast has a fairly robust and well 
maintained SSL infrastructure on its SMTP servers. To help ensure I 
get a verified *and* encrypted outbound connection, I've twiddled 
/etc/mail/access just a bit:

   TLS_Srv:smtp.comcast.net        VERIFY:128

I get rewarded with mail log entries that confirm the connection:

   Jul 29 16:23:11 irvine sm-mta[17049]: STARTTLS=client,
   relay=smtp.comcast.net.,version=TLSv1/SSLv3, verify=OK,
   cipher=AES256-SHA, bits=256/256

256-bit AES? Not bad! At the very least, it keeps messages safe from 
the prying eyes of snoopy neighbors. :-)

Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

From rsteff at comcast.net  Sun Jul 30 13:44:42 2006
From: rsteff at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Sun, 30 Jul 2006 13:44:42 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Converting Cassettes to computer files
In-Reply-To: <20060730074654.ec34748a.jmpurser@gmail.com>
References: <20060730074654.ec34748a.jmpurser@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <44CD1A3A.4020805@comcast.net>

John Purser wrote:

> Has anyone on this list played one full side of
> a tape into a computer, then used a program to break out the individual
> songs?
> 
> Any tips, hints, and tutorials would be appreciated.

I have used gramofile for recording cassette tapes, as well as LP's.

http://freshmeat.net/projects/gramofile/

While not perfect, gramofile does a reasonable job of locating the 
breaks between tracks. For conversion to MP3, I've used BladeEnc.

http://freshmeat.net/projects/gramofile/

Both are command line programs. Gramofile has a curses user interface, 
and BladeEnc allows wild cards to permit conversion of multiple files 
with a single invocation.

Gramofile also has decent scratch and pop filtering. I just use the 
default filter and have been happy with it. I've never tried mixing and 
matching from the other possibilities that also come with gramofile.

Like most mp3 encoders, BladeEnc will let you choose the bit rate you 
want. I understand a lot of folks are happy with 128. It really depends 
on the kind of music you are listening to, and how fussy your ears are. 
I use 256 for classical music. I can tell the difference between 256 and 
192. I can't tell the difference between 256 and 3xx (whatever the 
number is that's supposed to be as good as a CD).

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

years ago. High up on Google for Linux's list on BladeEnc is the following:

The page dates back to 2000, but I would guess that the issue never went 
away. The source code remains available, but binaries were taken down. 
So, if Snyaptic only pulls in binaries, there wouldn't be any available.

From daniel at digitree.org  Mon Jul 31 06:38:03 2006
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 2006 06:38:03 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Not Resolved,	but back to normal: Can't see files with
	Konqueror
In-Reply-To: <44CAA401.2020408@comcast.net>
References: <44CA97A1.4070402@comcast.net> <44CAA401.2020408@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <44CE07BB.2000603@digitree.org>

Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> Restarting X didn't change anything, but restarting the computer did. 
> The shutdown process hung when it tried to unmount the /home 
> directory, saying something about it being busy
How is your partition table laid out?  Is '/home' on a second hard disk 
from the '/' directory?  If so, your second hard disk could've stopped 
responding for some unknown reason (check your logs) or it could be an 
impending hardware failure.  Look into SMART tools to see if the disk 
has any problems (ex. "smartctl -a /dev/hdb").

Although you could see the directory structure of your home directory, 
there is a good chance that information was cached in memory and didn't 
need to access the hard disk.  Konqueror, on the other hand, would 
probably need to load up cached file preview images and such that might 
not have already been cached in memory.  It's interesting that, provided 
enough memory, a hard disk can crash and people won't even realize it 
for minutes or even hours; so long as everything was previously accessed 
and cached in memory.  This could explain why your email client worked 
to post your problems.

Cheers,

Daniel Hedlund

> 	I'm not sure why this is, since I test-ran Knoppix v4 on the floor model before I purchased the new laptop and it ran fine, reading from the DVD-Burner with no problems.
This is very odd behavior since Knoppix is Debian-based.  Are you sure 
that Knoppix actually detected the drive and not just did like the 
Debian installer?

I did a little bit of searching around on the Internet and it appears 
that there are quite a few problems related to serial-ATA (SATA) based 
CD-ROM drives.  Apparently you might try turning off ACPI support in the 
kernel (kernel arg "acpi=off").  Some places also seem to say that some 
chipsets require certain drivers to be detected properly.  Mostly 
though, these tips don't seem to help anyone.  Your kernel seems new 
enough.  I'll provide a few links to other people having similar 
problems that you can refer to for updates, but it might be worth taking 
this problem to the Linux kernel mailing list (especially look at first 
link below):
https://launchpad.net/distros/ubuntu/+source/cdrom-detect/+bug/21860
http://www.linuxforums.org/forum/mandriva-linux-help/23081-installation-cant-detect-sata-harddrive.html
http://forums.debian.net/viewtopic.php?t=6811&
http://www.linuxforums.org/forum/debian-linux-help/49509-setup-cannot-detect-cd-rom-breezy-badger-after-starting-initialisation-steps.html

Just to make sure before you go to the kernel list...you don't have a 
"/dev/hdc" (or equiv.) listed, correct?  If you do, double check ripping 
an ISO or something first ("dd if=/dev/hdc of=test.iso).

Also, double-check the kernel bootup messages to see if your CD-writer 
is mentioned anywhere in there; it might present an error or warning 
message about it.

Cheers,

Daniel Hedlund
daniel at digitree.org

From daniel at digitree.org  Mon Jul 31 08:33:59 2006
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)

Subject: [PLUG] Morning Slugishness
In-Reply-To: <868xmfqzya.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <44C791F6.6040208@comcast.net>	<c29537840607260944r70ff216em9b68e39834c6343b@mail.gmail.com>	<20060726221301.GA22055@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<868xmfqzya.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <44CE22E7.1010103@digitree.org>

Russell Senior wrote:
>   # swapoff -a
>   # swapon -a
>
> The first will page all the swapped out data back into RAM, the second
> will re-enable swap.
>   
Could this be dangerous to run on a system with only 192 MB memory?  
What would happen if he is actually using more memory than he has 
physically available?  Would swapoff just bork with an error instead of 
killing the system or apps?
> And, in Keith's case it ought to be fairly easy to add the operation
> to the end of his backup script
Again, I would hate to see what happens after waking up one morning to 
find a corrupt Inbox.  I think the following URLs have a much more 
appropriate solution, which is to tweak the swappiness settings of the 
kernel.  For example, "/var/sys/vm/swappiness" on my computer is 
currently set to "60".  If I change the value to a low number such as 10 
(or even 0, "echo 10 > /var/sys/vm/swappiness") just before running 
updatedb, the kernel will be very unlikely to swap out any memory unless 
it really really has to.  Once updatedb is done, you can set the 
swappiness back to its previous value:
http://lwn.net/Articles/83588/
http://kerneltrap.org/node/3000

However, I think the easiest solution would be to either disable 
updatedb in the nightly cron job and make run it once a week.

There is also apparently a patch being proposed (not sure if it's been 
implemented in the main trunk yet), which would automatically reload 
certain applications back into memory after they've been paged out to 
swap (http://members.optusnet.com.au/ckolivas/kernel/index.html).

Cheers,

Daniel Hedlund
daniel at digitree.org

> > opportunity for people trying to find a way in.

> make them local-only, and close the tunnel whenever you aren't
> personally using it?  I fail to see how this is less secure than not
> using encryption.

How many people here know how to enable WEP, IPSEC, etc?  I don't.  I use 
hostap, when it comes to WEP I've never been able to get a working 
connection.

Makes me wonder if IPSec is a better approach than trying to figure out
WEP, but I've never done that either, even for wired networks.

When it comes to secure networking, anyone get confused with Kerberos,
OpenLDAP, IPsec, etc. being wrapped into many of the standard Linux
packages?  How many people understand PAM?  I don't get PAM.  I'd
say most people don't know how to use ANY of the security options
available in Linux while the sheer number of encryption/security/authentication
methods tied onto even the smallest package set Linux will install with is
daunting to say the least.  I'd say Linux is too obscure when it comes to
encryption, especially wireless encryption.

Rogan is right, the service is ssh where tunneling is merely a particular
application of that service.

The obscurity of packages being built for various and asundry
encryption/authentication methods needs to be closely visited
in my opinion and cleaned up.  I don't see why Linux systems
even need PAM.  Packges should be set up for 0 
authentication/encryption methods by default and you should be 
able to install one method with the package dependencies set
up for that.  Should I really have to force krb5-libs off 
because sendmail insists that it depends on it even if it isn't
being used?

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Mon Jul 31 09:26:53 2006
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Tony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 2006 09:26:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fun with IPTables
In-Reply-To: <1154121151.44ca7dbff0c9d@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <55cf303a0607271411q23997964m1209433384c9aac@mail.gmail.com>

Message-ID: <200607310926.53945.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Friday 28 July 2006 14:12, plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:
[snip]
>
> How many people here know how to enable WEP, IPSEC, etc?  I don't.  I use
> hostap, when it comes to WEP I've never been able to get a working
> connection.
>
> Makes me wonder if IPSec is a better approach than trying to figure out
> WEP, but I've never done that either, even for wired networks.

In terms of supporting WEP or WPA I've never found Linux as easy to configure 
as WinXP. But with a little bit of effort I've been able to use both WEP and 
WPA-PSK with Linux. WEP is easy as I've used a program like "kwifimanager" 
for setting up WEP for several networks. It's also possible to set the WEP 
key on WIFI from the command line using "iwconfig" and I've done it with a 
simple shell script that scanned the available WIFI networks and when it 
detected a network ID is recognized it set the WEP key accordingly. 

WEP is so easy to crack though that I generally avoid using it for any WIFI 
network that I manage. When I did have to use WEP I went through extreme 
measures and put the WIFI side of the network on its own subnet and used an 
OpenBSD firewall with "authpf" support. To get to the internal side of the 
network users had to login to the firewall via SSH which caused "authpf" to 
dynamically update the firewall rules to allow packages from the given WIFI 
client to traverse from the WIFI subnet to the internal network. When the SSH 
session was closed the firewall rules were updated to remove the WIFI 
client's ability to access the internal network.

For WPA secured WIFI networks though I felt like I had to jump through a few 
hoops since an extra daemon process is required to  support WPA using a 
program called "wpa_supplicant". Unless one's Linux disto supplied a working 
version of the "wpa_supplicant" it has to be build with support for whatever 
WIFI chipset is being used. I wasn't able to get the WIFI drivers included 
with SuSE 9.2 to work with with the "wpa_supplicant" daemon so I had to 
resort getting a newer version of the ipw2200 and ieee80211XXX drivers from 
sourceforge and building them myself. 

With the updated Intel drivers I was able to get WPA-PSK support working but 
anytime I installed an updated kernel from SuSE  I'd have to rebuild my WIFI 
drivers and install my updates over the SuSE supplied kernel modules to get 
WPA support working again which made me dread installing kernel updates 
because of the extra work involved..

I was so happy when I upgraded to SuSE 10.0 though as they included support 
for WPA into YaST2 so it was just a simple matter of setting my passphrase 
and allowing YaST2 to automatically install the "wpa_supplicant" package. I 
had held off upgrading for months for fear of breaking my WIFI support since 
I wasn't sure if SuSE 10.0 would fix or break my WPA-PSK support.

Sorry for the long post but IMHO I think more work needs to be done for WIFI 
support for both WEP and WPA in Linux. Support is there and one just needs to 
figure out what to use depending on what encryption method a given WIFI 
network needs. But I wish it was as easy to configure WIFI support as it is 
under WinXP. 

Tony.

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

On Sun, Jul 30, 2006 at 07:46:53AM -0700, John Purser wrote:
> Has anyone on this list played one full side of a tape into a
> computer, then used a program to break out the individual songs?

I've used 'mp3splt' with reasonable success in the past. It basically
listens for quiet spots and splits the file accordingly. Sometimes it
goofs, but if you don't mind fiddling a bit, you can "tune" it to
better suit the sort of audio you're working with. Note that it only
works with pre-existing MP3/Ogg files, so you'd have to do the capture
and initial encoding some other way.

  Mp3Splt is a command line utility to split MP3 (VBR supported) and
  Ogg Vorbis files into smaller files without decoding. Useful for
  splitting albums, either manually, using freedb.org data, or .cue
  files and for splitting based on length or on periods of silence in
  the file.

<http://mp3splt.sourceforge.net/mp3splt_page/home.php>

	<1154121151.44ca7dbff0c9d@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
	<65244f100607311050m7128ee70p1a9a50146f416446@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <c834ec80607311133l7a5e3f9amaee4f91d78b8a4ec@mail.gmail.com>

On 7/31/06, Tim Slighter <tcslighter at gmail.com> wrote:
> I believe your comments are more about perspective, are we looking at this
> in terms of from my home computer to the demarc or are we looking at it from
> the ISP to the destination.  If we are talking about from the ISP to the
> destination then that is something we have absolutely no control over and
> wired or wireless would not really even matter.

I think you missed a critical portion of my reply.. If you have
complete controll over the entire path that your packets take, then
wired is more secure.  eg: your laptop to your hub, to your server,
assuming your server is connected to your hub, with arbitrary chaining
in between, but *ONLY* if you have complete controll over who has
access to all the intermediate networks, and you trust all those
connections.

The moment you leave a network that you controll, then all bets are off.

There is no way to know if the connection from your isp prevents
another one of their users from running a packet sniffer, which is
trivial to use, and requires no "specialized" equipment at all.  While
it's unlikely, it's also possible that there is a wireless link
somewhere between your connection to your ISP and the destination
you're communicating with -- you have no way to prove this one way or
the other, so you should assume the worst.

The point I was trying to make is that, like servers, networks are
insecure as long as some one has access to them.  Comparing wired
networks to wireless networks in the context of the entire internet is
like comparing a boat with one large hole in the bottom to a boat with
two large holes in the bottom -- the boat is sinking either way, so
you've got to take the same precautions in both cases.

--Rogan

> home computer to what could be either a wireless access point or in the case

Subject: [PLUG] Morning Slugishness
In-Reply-To: <44CE22E7.1010103@digitree.org>
References: <44C791F6.6040208@comcast.net>
	<c29537840607260944r70ff216em9b68e39834c6343b@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060726221301.GA22055@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<868xmfqzya.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <44CE22E7.1010103@digitree.org>
Message-ID: <86ac6pcx1n.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Daniel" == Daniel Hedlund <daniel at digitree.org> writes:

Daniel> [...] If I change the value to a low number such as 10 (or
Daniel> even 0, "echo 10 > /var/sys/vm/swappiness") just before
Daniel> running updatedb, the kernel will be very unlikely to swap out
Daniel> any memory unless it really really has to.  Once updatedb is
Daniel> done, you can set the swappiness back to its previous value:
Daniel> http://lwn.net/Articles/83588/ http://kerneltrap.org/node/3000

Won't solve the problem (of applications laggily swapping back in).
Rsync on big jobs chews up lots of RAM (has to maintain a lookup of
visited inodes in order to get hardlinks right).  That pressure is apt
to push idle jobs out of RAM.

Daniel> However, I think the easiest solution would be to either
Daniel> disable updatedb in the nightly cron job and make run it once
Daniel> a week.

Not a solution to nightly backups.  The nightliness is a desired feature.

Daniel> There is also apparently a patch being proposed (not sure if
Daniel> it's been implemented in the main trunk yet), which would
Daniel> automatically reload certain applications back into memory
Daniel> after they've been paged out to swap
Daniel> (http://members.optusnet.com.au/ckolivas/kernel/index.html).

The ability to do something like that on a per-process basis could
solve the problem.  Something like: swapin $(pidof mozilla)

Depending on the situation/machine, though, my swapoff/swapon trick
will work too.  Thanks for pointing out the caution though.  I am not
sure what happens if swapoff can't swap everything back in.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From daniel at digitree.org  Mon Jul 31 16:18:01 2006
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)

Subject: [PLUG] Morning Slugishness

References: <44C791F6.6040208@comcast.net>	<c29537840607260944r70ff216em9b68e39834c6343b@mail.gmail.com>	<20060726221301.GA22055@gate.kl-ic.com>	<868xmfqzya.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<44CE22E7.1010103@digitree.org> <86ac6pcx1n.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <44CE8FA9.2000004@digitree.org>

Russell Senior wrote:
> The ability to do something like that on a per-process basis could
> solve the problem.  Something like: swapin $(pidof mozilla)
>
>   
That's a really good idea!  Why can't a process's memory be swapped back 
in or accessed on a per-process basis with a command like you 
suggested?  Examples being:
$> proctouch $pid
$> proctouch (with a syntax similar to killall)

This could be done as a script using existing files in the /proc 
directories as each process has it's own listing of memory, maps, etc.  
It should even be possible to "touch"(cat to /dev/null) all a process's 
shared library dependencies by accessing the process's "maps" file and 
getting the memory addresses of such.

This could also be done as a C application and possibly use built-in 
library functions in the kernel or another standard library (not sure 
which one would have everything needed).

I think I have become obsessed and will try to see if I can implement 
part of this tonight.  :)  I will start with script-based attempts 
though and might look into a C-api if I get time in the coming days.

Cheers,

Daniel Hedlund
daniel at digitree.org

On Mon, 31 Jul 2006, Dale F. Victor wrote:

> I have a Acer Aspire 1800 running Kubuntu. Worked great until a few days
> ago. It now powers on for about 5 seconds and then shuts down. SO I guess

Dale,

   It looks like it may be a power supply problem. The brick may not be
recharging the battery or running the unit even when it's plugged in the
wall outlet.

   I had this problem on the ol' ThinkPad. The fine folks at Northwest
Computer Support (in southwest Beaverton) fixed me up with a new A/C power
supply after confirming that was the problem.

   They've done all the repairs and stuff on my portables. Despite the
distance, I find them worth the trip.

Rich

From daniel at digitree.org  Mon Jul 31 20:23:16 2006
From: daniel at digitree.org (Daniel Hedlund)
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 2006 20:23:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Help with Acer Laptop
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0607311944500.11858@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <200607311631.34278.dalefv@k-com.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0607311944500.11858@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <44CEC924.9040702@digitree.org>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   It looks like it may be a power supply problem. The brick may not be
> recharging the battery or running the unit even when it's plugged in the
> wall outlet.

In addition to what Rich suggests, I've had two separate instances where 
the power connector to the mainboard on the laptop has come loose or 
unsoldered.  The power brick may still be okay.  You can test this by 
using an ammeter on the end of the cable...or for those people who are 
poor or stupid enough like myself, you could always try sticking your 
tongue on the end of the cord; this might at least rule out the brick.

If the brick is okay, depending on how skilled you are, you could try 
taking your laptop apart.  Don't do this if it's still under warranty.  
With most laptops, it's quite difficult to get down to the mainboard 
where the power connector is to have a look or take the board out to 
resolder it.

Cheers,

Daniel Hedlund
daniel at digitree.org

# from Russell Senior
# on Monday 31 July 2006 01:57 pm:

>Depending on the situation/machine, though, my swapoff/swapon trick
>will work too. ?Thanks for pointing out the caution though. ?I am not
>sure what happens if swapoff can't swap everything back in.

What if you have an identically-sized swapfile $file (not in fstab)

  swapon $file && swapoff -a && swapon -a && swapoff $file

Would that page everything into ram on the way to the swapfile and then 
(typically) happily notice that it fits with overflow going to the file 
only if needed?

Could be a spare swap partition, but the file would be a bit more 
flexible (it's only a safety net, so swapfile performance suckage 
doesn't matter much here.)

--Eric
